'''Football for Peace''' is a non-governmental organisation (NGO) with its headquarters in London and supported by the [[United Nations Office on Sport for Development and Peace]]. It was co-founded internationally in 2013 by English-born Pakistani footballer [[Kashif Siddiqi]] and Chilean [[FIFA]] legend [[Elías Figueroa|Elias Figueroa]].
== History == Originally started by Figueroa in 2006 as a campaign known as Futbol Por la Paz in South America. Siddiqi became the co-founder of Football for Peace Global in 2013 and in the same year, the concept made the transition from "campaign" to implementing NGO status with its international incorporation. The initiative was based on what had been achieved in the Americas, and brought to Europe, Asia, the Middle East, Africa and the Far East.
== Global Football for Peace process == In 2015, Football for Peace Global created a peace process<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://footballforpeaceglobal.org/about-us/#approach|title=About Us – Football for Peace – Our History|newspaper=Football for Peace|language=en-US|access-date=6 November 2016}}</ref> which is inclusive of peace matches, legacy projects known as "City for Peace" and sports diplomacy toolkits influencing social change. The process was intended to focus on community integration, reducing tensions between different groups and creating dialogue between nations.
=== Peace process lobbying === Football for Peace hosted [[Joko Widodo]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.newhamrecorder.co.uk/news/president_of_indonesia_pops_by_for_kickaround_at_newham_school_1_4504798|title=President of Indonesia pops by for kickaround at Newham school|last=Burns|first=Iain|newspaper=Newham Recorder|access-date=6 November 2016}}</ref> 7th president of Indonesia in East London to showcase the peace process on 20 April 2016. He was accompanied by the British government officials where they met 60 youngsters from Newham, London and three Football for Peace ambassadors from Birmingham, who participated in the day-long workshop at Chobham Academy, Newham.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.indonesia-investments.com/news/news-columns/joko-widodo-visits-europe-germany-britain-belgium-and-the-netherlands/item6748|title=Joko Widodo Visits Europe: Germany, Britain, Belgium and the Netherlands {{!}} Indonesia Investments|last=Investments|first=Indonesia|website=www.indonesia-investments.com|access-date=6 November 2016}}</ref>
At the event, the NGO showcased educational football diplomacy toolkits which included youth leadership programs in bringing together youths from different backgrounds, religions and ethnicities.
In October 2016, co-founder of Football for Peace, Kashif Siddiqi was invited to meet [[Pope Francis]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/londonborn-footballer-kashif-siddiqi-out-to-prove-the-beautiful-game-can-do-good-on-vatican-visit-a3360071.html|title=Kashif Siddiqi out to prove football can do good on Vatican visit|date=3 October 2016|newspaper=London Evening Standard|language=en-GB|access-date=6 November 2016}}</ref> and launch the first "Sport at the service of Humanity" at a press conference,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.romereports.com/2016/10/04/vatican-presents-world-conference-on-sport-and-faith|title=Vatican presents world conference on sport and faith|publisher=romereports.com|access-date=6 November 2016}}</ref> which was organised by the [[Pontifical Council for Culture]] under the leadership of Cardinal [[Gianfranco Ravasi]] at the [[Vatican City|Vatican]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://press.vatican.va/content/salastampa/en/bollettino/pubblico/2016/10/04/161004b.html|title=Presentation of the event 'Sport at the Service of Humanity'|website=press.vatican.va|access-date=6 November 2016}}</ref> and welcomed the presence of faith leaders.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://uk.news.yahoo.com/peacemaker-kashif-siddiqi-meet-pope-150413530.html|title=Peacemaker Kashif Siddiqi to meet Pope Francis and launch first 'Sport and Humanity' conference at Vatican|access-date=6 November 2016}}</ref> Siddiqi spoke on the Global Peace Process and the role sport has to unite.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.sg/kashif-siddiqi-uses-football-analogy-explain-how-he-want-bring-peace-3749|title=Football for Peace at Vatican: Kashif Siddiqi explains how sport can unite people|last=Ullal|first=Naveen|newspaper=International Business Times, Singapore Edition|language=en|access-date=6 November 2016}}</ref>
== Peace matches and Cities for Peace ==
=== Peace Match 2015 === On 8 September 2015, the first international peace match was hosted with the Royal Navy in bringing together Great Britain and Afghanistan. It marked the end of war against the Taliban group in Afghanistan and promoted reconciliation between the nations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://afghanistanembassy.org.uk/english/?p=218|title=Afghanistan-England football match could mark end of Taliban war {{!}} Embassy of Afghanistan in London|publisher=afghanistanembassy.org.uk|access-date=6 November 2016}}</ref> It was a five aside peace match, which involved members of the Afghanistan national team and Team Great Britain playing together in the same team against a Footballers for Peace side at the old Royal Naval college in London Greenwich.
The unified Afghanistan and Great Britain was led by former [[Premier League]] manager [[Harry Redknapp]], who defeated the Footballers for Peace side in front of a crowd, which included [[Prince Ali bin Hussein|Prince Ali bin al-Hussein]] of Jordan.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sitecoreadmin.thepfa.com/news/2015/9/11/football-for-peace-and-her-majestys-royal-navy-peace-match-afghanistan-and-great-britain|title=Football For Peace & Her Majesty's Royal Navy Peace Match – Afghanistan & Great Britain|last=Peace|first=Football for|website=sitecoreadmin.thepfa.com|access-date=6 November 2016}}</ref>
=== City for Peace 2015 === In December 2015,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-3349312/Prince-William-shows-ball-skills-football-academy-Birmingham.html|title=Prince William shows off his ball skills at a football academy|newspaper=Daily Mail|access-date=6 November 2016}}</ref> HRH [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Prince William, The Duke of Cambridge]] and Mr [[Wilfried Lemke]] The United Nations Secretary-General's Special Adviser on Sport for Development and Peace attended Birmingham for peace project and recognised the young peace ambassadors in the city.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/wcm/content/site/sport/home/sport/template/news_item.jsp?cid=42723|title=United Nations Sport for Development and Peace – WHY SPORT?|publisher=United Nations|language=en|access-date=6 November 2016}}</ref> The project was based in Birmingham's Saltley Academy and was intended to bring young children from different faith and cultural backgrounds together after [[Operation Trojan Horse]] in 2014.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-birmingham-28370552|title=Trojan Horse 'plot' schools timeline|date=16 July 2015|publisher=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=6 November 2016}}</ref>
=== City for Peace 2016 === In January 2016, a women's empowerment program was launched in [[Kozhikode]], a coastal city in the south Indian state of Kerala with Brazilian football legend [[Ronaldinho|Ronaldinho Gaucho]] announced an ambassador. He said, "Football has the power to unite the people. It has given me an opportunity and taught me universal values of Friendship and Unity. I am supporting the work carried by Football for Peace Global and proud to be the Guest of Honour of [[2016 Sait Nagjee Trophy]] tournament and becoming a footballer for peace".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/football/top-stories/Brazilian-legend-Ronaldinho-inaugurates-Sait-Nagjee-Cup/articleshow/50708525.cms|title=Brazilian legend Ronaldinho inaugurates Sait Nagjee Cup|newspaper=The Times of India|access-date=6 November 2016}}</ref>
Football for Peace worked with Sait Nagjee Trophy Tournament, which is one of the most prestigious tournaments held in Kozhikode.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} It was the first edition of the tournament in 21 years and the 2016 edition saw clubs from Ukraine, Germany, Brazil, England and Republic of Ireland take part, along with the Argentina U23 side.
FC Dnipro Reserves won the tournament, while Atlético Paranaense Reserves finished as the runners-up in a tournament that was held between 5 and 21 February 2016.
Working with the 2016 Sait Nagjee Trophy Tournament and Kozhikode District Football Association,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/sport/report-brazilian-legend-ronaldinho-wows-fans-in-2169886|title=Brazilian legend Ronaldinho wows fans in Kozhikode {{!}} Latest News & Updates at Daily News & Analysis|date=24 January 2016|newspaper=dna|language=en-US|access-date=6 November 2016}}</ref> the organisations cooperated to involve teams from differing nations in tournaments.
After the tournament, Football for Peace delivered a legacy programme dedicated to the female youth of different areas in Kerala, which was intended to allow them to promote empowerment, cultural exchange and peace between various communities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.catchnews.com/football-news/after-ronaldinho-visit-football-for-peace-sets-sights-on-india-pakistan-football-friendly-1453907430.html|title=After Ronaldinho visit, Football for Peace sets sights on India-Pakistan football friendly|publisher=CatchNews.com|access-date=6 November 2016}}</ref>
== Structure ==
The Football for Peace organisation is based on three main structures: the Executive Board, the Steering Committee, the Footballers for Peace Council, the NGO is directed by the three structures and governed by [[Hogan Lovells]], a multinational [[law firm]] co-headquartered in London and Washington, D.C.
== References == <!-- Inline citations added to your article will automatically display here. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WP:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. --> {{reflist|30em}}

{{Infobox officeholder |image = Ulysses S Grant by Brady c1870-restored.jpg |caption='''President Grant'''
'''''Circa 1870''''' |order = 18th |office = President of the United States |term_start = March 4, 1869 |term_end = March 4, 1877 |birth_name = Hiram Ulysses Grant |birth_date = {{Birth date|1822|4|27}} |birth_place = [[Point Pleasant, Ohio]], U.S. |death_date = {{Death date and age|1885|7|23|1822|4|27}} |death_place = [[Wilton, New York]], U.S. |restingplace = [[Grant's Tomb|General Grant National Memorial]]
[[Manhattan]], New York |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] }} {{Ulysses Grant sidebar}} '''Grantism''' became a byword by his political opponents and ''[[Lost Cause]]'' supporters, directed at [[President of the United States|President]] [[Ulysses S. Grant]] for political incompetence, corruption and fraud during his administration in the 1870s. The 1869–1877 [[presidency of Ulysses S. Grant]] was marred by many scandals and fraudulent activities associated with persons within his [[Federal government of the United States#Executive branch|administration]], including his [[Cabinet of the United States|cabinet]], that was in continual transition, divided by the forces of political corruption and reform.{{cite book|last=Hinsdale|first=Mary Louise|year=1911 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C6Re1rvM9nMC&printsec=frontcover&dq=A+history+of+the+President's+cabinet&cd=1#v=onepage&q=&f=false|title=A History of the President's Cabinet|location=Ann Arbor, MI|publisher=G. Wahr|pages=207, 212–213}} Among them were: [[Black Friday (1869)|Black Friday]], corruption in the [[Department of the Interior]], the [[Sanborn incident]], and the [[Whiskey Ring]]. (The [[Crédit Mobilier of America scandal|Crédit Mobilier scandal]], although exposed during his tenure, is not considered a Grant scandal.) Some historians defend Grant noting he was the first President to establish the Civil Service Commission, had reformers on his Cabinet, and he ended the corrupt moiety system of privateer tax collectors profiteering by taking a percentage of delinquent taxes. His enemies wanted to undermine the moral integrity of his administration and for his enforcement of [[African American]] civil rights during [[Reconstruction Era|Reconstruction]]. Grant, ever trusting of associates, was himself influenced by both forces. The standards in many of his appointments were low, and charges of corruption were widespread. Although not directly involved with these scandals, the president's associations with people of questionable character and his reliance on [[cronyism]], [[nepotism]], and [[political patronage]] gave rise to accusations of "Grantism". Historians agree that corruption in the Grant administration was due to Grant's unqualified appointments of close friends and family, and remain perplexed why he protected [[Orville E. Babcock]] his personal secretary. ==Origins== [[Image:Charles Sumner Brady-Handy.jpg|thumb|260px|U.S. Senator [[Charles Sumner]] (1851-1874) in a photograph by [[Mathew Brady]], 1865]] The term "Grantism" was originally coined by fellow Republican Senator [[Charles Sumner]] in a speech on May 31, 1872, a Presidential election year. It was used by Sumner to differentiate the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] from Grant. The two men had been political enemies ever since Sumner's refusal to annex [[Dominican Republic|Santo Domingo]] to the United States. Sumner accused Grant of political patronage, nepotism, and being an autocrat like [[Julius Caesar]]. Sumner charged that Grant had hindered [[African American]] [[national sovereignty]] rights in the [[Caribbean]] with the [[Annexation of Santo Domingo|annexation proposal of Santo Domingo]]. Sumner was also angry that Grant used his personal secretary to establish international relations with Santo Domingo, rather than acting through the [[U.S. State Department|State Department]] and [[U.S. Congress|Congress]]. Sumner summed up Grantism as a [[despotic]] government of "one man and his personal will".{{cite web |last=Sumner|first=Charles|title=Republicanism vs. Grantism|url=https://archive.org/stream/republicanismvsg00sumn#page/n1/mode/2up|date=May 31, 1872}} The lengthy speech was used as the political platform for the [[Liberal Republican Party (United States)|Liberal Republican Party]] and launched the political career of [[Horace Greeley]] as the party's presidential candidate in 1872. ==Grant as reformer== {{Further|Ulysses S. Grant presidential administration reforms}} Historian Louis Arthur Coolidge noted that although Grant had critics, including Sumner, concerning presidential patronage, he was the first president to advocate and sign into law [[United States federal civil service|civil service]] reform legislation on March 4, 1871.Coolidge (1922), ''Ulysses S. Grant'', pp. 399-400 Grant said that the "elevation and purification of civil service of the government will be hailed with approval by the whole people of the United States". The historians H. Wayne Morgan and [[Ari Hoogenboom]] say that Grant's presidential reputation for corruption has been exaggerated.McFeely-Woodward (1974), ''Responses of the Presidents to Charges of Misconduct'', pp. 133-134 Grant placed leading reformer [[George William Curtis]] as head of the civil service commission set up to establish regulations, in order to ensure the best person qualified would hold office. In addition to signing the civil service reform, Grant limited and finally abolished the [[wiktionary:moiety|moiety]] system in which private citizens contracted as [[U.S. Treasury|Treasury]] revenue agents and received a percentage of delinquent taxes assessed and collected. ==Modern definitions== The Liberal Republicans defined "corruption in government" to mean Grantism from 1873-1875.{{cite web |title=Reconstruction The Second Civil War|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/reconstruction/states/sf_timeline2.html|date=December 19, 2003}} The Liberal Republicans ceased to exist after the reforming [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] assumed a majority in the [[U.S. House of Representatives]] from 1875-1881. After assuming control of the House, the Democrats launched a series of corruption investigations into the [[Ulysses S. Grant presidential administration|Grant Administration]] from 1875-1876. Today, "Grantism" is defined as any political corruption and greed in government. During Grant's presidency, many of his associates took part in [[price skimming]] and [[tax evasion]]. "Grantism" also refers to big business undermining control of local and national government. ==References== [[Category:Presidency of Ulysses S. Grant]] [[Category:Presidential scandals in the United States]] [[Category:Political corruption in the United States]] [[Category:Grant administration controversies| ]] [[Category:1822 births]] [[Category:1885 deaths]] [[Category:Eponymous political ideologies]]

*[[Siege of Sarajevo]] | notable_commanders = Emin Švrakić | anniversaries = | decorations = }} '''Zelene beretke''' (English, "'''Green Berets'''") was a paramilitary organization founded in [[Sarajevo]] in early 1992. They were founded by demobilized soldiers and conscripts from the [[Yugoslav National Army]] (JNA) who were mostly ethnic [[Bosniaks]] and supporters of [[Bosnian nationalism]]. They were integrated into a newly founded [[Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] in the second half of 1992. The Green Berets as a gear of choice and name was selected both as a reference to United States Army Special Forces (although no actual relation existed) and as a common colour brand of the predominant ethnic group that composed the unit, namely [[Bosniaks]]. Bosnian Green Berets were mostly active during the war in the early part of 1992 in northern and central Bosnia.{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N23MpUgJfswC&pg=PA284&dq=Zelene+beretke&client=firefox-a | title=This was not our war: Bosnian women reclaiming the peace | accessdate=March 1, 2011 | author=Swanee Hunt}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== *[[Green Berets]] {{Army of the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina}} [[Category:Military units and formations of the Bosnian War]] [[Category:Paramilitary organizations in the Yugoslav Wars]] [[Category:Military wings of political parties]] [[Category:Disbanded units and formations]] {{mil-unit-stub}} {{BosniaHerzegovina-stub}} {{Mil-hist-stub}}

The '''Grupo Gay da Bahia''' or simply '''GGB''' ({{IPA-pt|ˈɡɾupu ˈɡej da bɐˈiˑ.jɐ|lang}}, ''Gay Group of Bahia'', {{IPA-pt|ʒeʒeˈbe|}}) is the oldest association for the defense of the [[Human rights in Brazil|human rights]] for [[homosexual]]s functioning in [[Brazil]]. Founded in 1980 by [[Luiz Mott]], in the city of [[Salvador, Bahia]], the GGB was registered as a non-profit organization in 1983, and was declared a public service [[organization]] of the city of Salvador in 1987. It is a member of the International Lesbian and Gay Association, it forms part of the staff of the International Lesbian and Gay Human Rights Commission, the National Association of Black and White Men Together, and it is a "twin" of the RFSL of Stockholm.
Since 1989, it has been a member of the [[Ministry of Health (Brazil)|Ministry of Heath's]] National Commission to Control AIDS, and since 1995 it has been one of the coordinators of the Secretariat of Human Rights of the Brazilian Association of [[Gay]]s, [[Lesbian]]s and [[Transvestite]]s. The GGB was directly responsible for the foundation of several groups in defense of the human rights of homosexuals in other states of Brazil, and it provides a meeting space for the Lesbian Group of Bahia, the Association of Transvestites of Salvador, and the Anti-AIDS Center of Bahia, entities which are allied with yet independent from the GGB. In 1985, the GGB promoted the Third Encounter of the Brazilian Homosexual Movement and in 1994, the Sixth Encounter of Brazilian AIDS NGO's. The group publishes the GGB Bulletin two or three times a year, and has produced two dozen pamphlets and booklets about homosexuality and AIDS. Marcelo Cerqueira is the current president of the GGB.
==Objectives== The GGB has three objectives: *To defend the [[rights]] to full [[citizenship]] for gays, lesbians, transvestites and transsexuals of [[Bahia]] and Brazil, denouncing and fighting against all manifestations of [[homophobia]] and [[sexual discrimination]]; *To spread accurate information about homosexuality, promoting the establishment of [[sexual education]] courses in all schools, to put an end to ignorance and the conspiracy of silence against the "love that [they] dare not speak its name" through a discourse which is scientifically and politically correct; *To promote awareness among the greatest possible number of gays, lesbians, transvestites and transsexuals about the urgent need to fight for their full [[civil rights]], as well as to give access to information and support regarding [[safe sex]], [[sexually transmitted disease]]s and [[AIDS]].
==Organization and functioning== The Gay Group of Bahia is coordinated by six non-salaried Directors, (President, Vice-president, Treasurer, and three Coordinators), elected for three years. Any citizen can become a member of the GGB, independent of sex, [[gender]], [[sexual orientation]], [[gender identity]] or expression, [[Race (classification of human beings)|race]] or [[ethnicity]], [[religion]], or [[List of political ideologies|political ideology]]: the GGB presently has 500 regular members. The GGB has its own center, offered by one of the directors, located at Rua Frei Vicente, 24 – Pelourinho. The space is made up of a three-storey house and holds a small library, an archive and an office with a telephone, fax and computer. It houses the largest archive of [[newspaper]]s, [[magazine]]s, and other printed material on the history of homosexuality and LGBT rights in Latin America. The center is open to the public during business hours.
Since its foundation, the GGB has held two weekly meetings, every Wednesday and Friday, from 8 to 10 p.m. These meetings are coordinated by the group’s Board of Directors and are dedicated to the discussion of topics of interest to the [[gay community]]. Between 100 and 200 people visit the GGB’s center every week, making the number of visitors during the group's 32 years of existence exceed 40,000. The following subgroups form part of the GGB: the Quimbanda-Dudu Group of Black Gays of Bahia; the Gay Stamp Association of Brazil; the Brazilian Association of Parents and Friends of Homosexuals; the Center for Homosexual Studies.<ref>[http://www.ggb.org.br/ggb-ingles.html Grupo Gay da Bahia - English version]</ref>

[[File:Versailles Palace.jpg|thumb|right| The [[Palace of Versailles]] where the 1919 discussions concerning Germany took place.]] The '''Heavenly Twins''' was the name assigned to two British delegates, the Judge [[John Andrew Hamilton, 1st Viscount Sumner|Lord Sumner]] and the Banker [[Walter Cunliffe, 1st Baron Cunliffe|Lord Cunliffe]], during the 1919 [[Treaty of Versailles]] negotiations who were to set the terms of the peace to be imposed on Germany following the end of [[World War I]]. The two lords, together with the Prime Minister of Australia [[Billy Hughes]], were responsible for presenting the British and [[Dominion|British Dominions']] case concerning the amount of compensatory payments, or [[World War I reparations|war reparations]], that were to be extracted from Germany.<ref name="Guilt">{{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/?id=V0UOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA33&lpg=PA33&dq=%22heavenly+twins%22+Cunliffe+and+Sumner#PPA32,M1 |title= Guilt at Versailles , p 33 - 38 , 55- 58 |publisher= Routledge and Google Books |author= Antony Lentin |accessdate=2009-06-14|isbn= 9780416411300 |year= 1984 }} </ref>
==Origin of the name the "Heavenly Twins"== There are mixed views on how the handle was coined. For [[Milo Keynes]],<ref> {{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/?id=s3qqM3B_920C&pg=PA168&lpg=PA168&dq=%22heavenly+twins%22+Cunliffe+and+Sumner |title= Essays on John Maynard Keynes, p 168 |publisher= Cambridge University Press and Google Books |author= Milo Keynes |accessdate=2009-06-14|isbn= 9780521296960 |year= 1975 }} </ref> the phrase was first used by the American diplomat [[Norman Davis (diplomat)|Norman Davis]]. While for historian Antony Lentin,<ref name = "Guilt"/> the phrase arose among younger members of the British delegation. There were three principal reasons: the "astronomically"<ref>The classical reference, more obvious in 1919 than today, was to the [[Dioscuri]], twin brothers who are linked with paried stars [[Castor (star)|Castor]] and [[Pollux (star)|Pollux]] of the [[Gemini (constellation)|constellation Gemini]].</ref> large sums the Twins thought should be extracted from Germany, the "beatific smile" they would sometimes both adopt after rendering a judgement in situations where they had the upper hand in a debate, and the fact they were generally inseparable at Versailles—both at work and while enjoying the Paris nightlife. Additionally, Britons in 1919 would have been well aware of [[Sarah Grand|Sarah Grand's]] [[New Woman]] novel ''The Heavenly Twins'', a much talked-about bestseller in 1893.<ref name = "Guilt"/><ref name = "Hope"> {{cite book |author = Carroll Quigley |title= Tragedy and Hope |year= 1995
|pages = 243, 263 |isbn= 0-945001-10-X |publisher= GSG & Associates, Inc }}</ref><ref> {{cite book |last=Skidelsky |first=Robert |title=John Maynard Keynes: Hopes Betrayed |year=1983 |isbn=0-333-57379-X |publisher =London: Macmillan}} </ref>
==The British position on reparations at Versailles==
===Pre conference dissension: the Heavenly Twins opposing Maynard Keynes=== [[File:1stViscountSumner.jpg|thumb|left|Lord Sumner, one of the Heavenly Twins.]] In the months leading up to the Versailles Conference, economist [[John Maynard Keynes]] had been assigned the task of defining the [[HM Treasury|British Treasuries']] position on the [[World War I reparations|amount of reparations]] Germans could be expected to pay. Keynes came up with a figure of £3,000 million, saying that in actuality receiving even a total of £2,000 million would be satisfactory.<ref name = "SkidelSVol" > {{cite book |last=Skidelsky |first=Robert |title=John Maynard Keynes: 1883-1946: Economist, Philosopher, Statesman |year=2003 |isbn=0-330-48867-8 |pages= 217–220 |publisher =Pan MacMillan Ltd }}</ref> A power bloc composed of businessmen and representatives of the Dominions, supported by conservative politicians, felt this was far too low, but in the autumn of 1918 the [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberals]] had the upper hand in the governing coalition, and key ministers generally supported Keynes's view, which he had expected to be able to present at Versailles. The balance of power shifted after the December [[United Kingdom general election, 1918|1918 coupon election]]. While the liberal [[Lloyd George]] was retained as Prime Minister, voter pressure generated by a determined press campaigning had caused him to adopt a hard line attitude towards Germany. Most of the other Liberal [[Member of parliament|MPs]] had lost their seats, including even the party leader [[H. H. Asquith]].
The new government commissioned an alternative committee to re-assess Germany's ability to pay, its members including Lord Cunliffe. The committee estimated that the Germans would be able to pay the full cost of the war at £24,000 million.<ref name = "SkidelSVol" /> While this figure was approximately eight times the annual [[Gross domestic product|GDP]] of Germany before the war, Lord Cunliffe still went on to speculate that he may have underestimated Germany's ability to pay, saying that if someone suggested Germany could pay in the region of £50,000 million he "would not disbelieve them".<ref name = "Lords"> {{cite book |author = Liaquat Ahamed |title= [[Lords of Finance]] |year= 2009 |chapter = Chpt 7 |isbn= 978-0-09-949308-2 |publisher= WindMill Books }}</ref>
It was decided that the Heavenly Twins would present Great Britain's case at the Versailles conference, with Keynes and the Treasury formerly excluded from high level talks. Keynes still attended Versailles, as the Treasuries' chief representative, with a broad remit to decide financial aspects of the transition to peace—he would still try to influence the reparations settlement by lobbying the decision makers through back channels. Other British attendees would support Keynes' view, including [[Jan Smuts]] the [[Prime Minister of South Africa|prime minister of South Africa]],<ref>Modern scholars have been critical of Smuts as his idealism didn't extend to taking a more than moderately strong line against [[apartheid]]. However at the time he was the most widely respected member of the British delegation at the council, a man who had a seminal influence on the League of Nations and later United Nations, who [[Einstein]] was later to say was one of only 12 people in the world to fully understand relativity. Smuts had called one of Keynes papers on reparations "masterly" and was a powerful supporter.</ref> [[Bonar Law]] the [[Chancellor of the Exchequer|Chancellor]], and [[Edwin Samuel Montagu|Edwin Montagu]] the [[Secretary of State for India]].<ref name = "SkidelSVol" />
===Debate on Reparations at the conference=== [[File:Big four.jpg|thumb|right| The Council of Four: from left, UK Prime Minister [[David Lloyd George|Lloyd George]], Italian Prime Minister [[Vittorio Emanuele Orlando|Orlando]], French Prime Minister [[Georges Clemenceau|Clemenceau]], and US President [[Woodrow Wilson|Wilson]].]] Leaders from [[Allies of World War I|32 allied nations]] were present at Versailles, but major decisions were made almost entirely by the Supreme War Council—briefly the ''Council of Ten'', later condensed to the ''Council of Four''. Referring to the Council of Four, Keynes asserted in his ''[[Economic Consequences of the Peace]]'' that if the world is to understand its destiny it had a great need of light: {{cquote|… on the complex struggle of human will and purpose, not yet finished, which, concentrated in the persons of four individuals in a manner never paralleled, made them, in the first months of 1919, the microcosm of mankind.}} The three principal decision makers were Britain's [[Lloyd George]], France's [[Georges Clemenceau|Clemenceau]] and America's [[Woodrow Wilson|President Wilson]]—the fourth council member, Italy's Prime Minister [[Vittorio Emanuele Orlando|Orlando]], had little to do with settling the reparations question.<ref name = "origins"> {{cite book |first = Frank |last= McDonough |chapter= 17 <!--|pages = 43–46--> |title = The Origins of the First and Second World Wars |year=1997 |pages= 85–106 |publisher= Cambridge University Press |isbn=1-4051-0664-6}} </ref> The allies deliberately excluded Germany from having any representative on the high level talks, mindful of the skill of German diplomats such as [[Ulrich Graf von Brockdorff-Rantzau|Count Brockdorff-Rantzau]] and the success [[Talleyrand]] had enjoyed at the [[Congress of Vienna]] in exploiting division among the victorious allies to win a very favourable settlement after [[Napoleon|Napoleon's]] defeat.<ref name = "companion"> {{cite book |editor=Gordon Martel |first = Alan |last= Sharp |chapter= 17 |pages = 266, 273 |title=A companion to Europe |year=2005 |publisher= WileyBlackwell |isbn=1-4051-0664-6}} </ref> Decisions by the top level council were informed by expert commissions. The Heavenly Twins sat on the commission dedicated to reparations. This commission was itself divided into three sub committees. The first was to assess how much each allied power deserved and in what proportion the moneys would be divided, assuming Germany was unable to pay the full total amount assessed. The second subcommittee was to assess Germany's ability to pay and the third to agree on ways to guarantee payment.
A key issue for the British in the first sub-committee was the American's insistence that compensation should only be awarded for damage to civilians and their property, not for military costs. Taken strictly this would mean by far the lion's share of compensation would go to the French—Britain and her Dominions had suffered huge losses to their armed forces but the fighting had been mainly on continental Europe, with British civilians scarcely hurt at all. Lord Sumner had presented the case that pensions paid to the widows of soldiers should count as civilian costs but the Americans did not agree and so the matter was escalated to the Council of Four, where President Wilson himself was said to reject Lord Sumners argument "almost with contempt".<ref name = "Guilt"/> Lloyd George then took a hand and, after several days, he was able to convince Smuts<ref>For Lentin one of the great mysteries of the conference, as Smuts was very much against a harsh settlement. Perhaps he'd been persuaded that including pensions would not raise the total amount paid by Germany, only the share awarded to Britain, although it did not work out that way. In despair at the way the treaty turned out Smuts agreed with Keynes that disaster was looming, and that it was time for Grigua's prayer "The Lord to come Himself and not to send His Son, as this is not a time for children"</ref> of the merits of Sumners case and got Smuts to re-approach Wilson. The same argument Wilson had roundly rejected from Lord Summer was accepted when put by Smuts who, like the President, was a Christian, a scholar, and an idealist. Other American delegates had tried to persuade Wilson that it was not logical to count pensions as civilian damages but he replied "Logic! Logic! I don't give a damn for logic. I am going to include pensions."<ref name = "Guilt"/> This led to an increase in the share that was to be awarded to Britain, and later would result in the total claim on Germany being increased as well.<ref name = "SkidelSVol" />
Lord Cunliffe chaired the subcommittee that was to determine Germany's capacity to pay. At first the Twins continued to insist Germany could pay £25bn but the US Treasury representatives [[Thomas W. Lamont]] and [[John Foster Dulles]], supported by [[Norman Davis (diplomat)|Norman Davis]], refused to hear of this and The Twins reduced their recommended figure to £8bn. The leading French representative on the commission, [[Louis Loucheur]], had told Davis off the record that he personally doubted the Germans could afford anywhere near this amount, but that he could not publicly advocate anything less than Lord Cunliff's figure.<ref name = "SkidelSVol" /> The Americans still opposed the revised amount and, after an escalation to the Council of Four, a secret alternative commission was set up consisting of Lamont, Loucheur and Montagu.<ref name = "SkidelSVol" /> This commission recommended the total amount to be extracted to be limited to about £5bn, but Lloyd George would not accept this unless Lord Cunliffe could be persuaded. In [[Robert Skidelsky, Baron Skidelsky|Robert Skidelsky's]] view, Lloyd George was afraid the Heavenly Twins would "crucify" him at Parliament if he agreed to too small a figure—the majority of MPs now being conservative with many also being businessmen. The Heavenly Twins, together with the French delegation and support from Lloyd George, continued to pressure the Americans who progressively gave ground from their initially strong position that only limited reparations should be imposed.
Keynes tried to argue against the Heavenly Twins but they rebuffed him, mockingly referring to him as "Herr von K". For most of the conference, Lloyd George himself would only take limited notice of Keynes's plea for moderation. Towards the end however, the prime minister began to show signs that he had moved towards Keynes' view.<ref name = "Lords"/> Keynes came up with a plan that he argued would not only help Germany and other impoverished central European powers, but would also be good for the world economy as a whole. It involved the writing down of war debts which would have the effect of increasing international trade all round. Lloyd George agreed that it might be acceptable to the British electorate. America was against it however, the US then being the largest creditor and also as by this time President Wilson had started to believe in the merits of a harsh peace as a warning to future aggressors.<ref name = "SkidelSVol" /> At the end of the conference a compromise conceived by Dulles was agreed on where Germany accepted a theoretically unlimited "[[Article 231 of the Treaty of Versailles|war guilt]]" obligation, but in practice the amount payable would be limited.<ref name = "Hope"/> Lloyd George worked to insure no firm figure was set by the conference's end, in the opinion of economic history writer [[Liaquat Ahamed]] his plan was to wait until the passions after the war had cooled, and then set about ensuring that a figure well below the Twin's recommendation was agreed on.<ref name = "Lords"/> By the close of the conference it was left open for the total to be far higher than Keynes's was happy about; the first firm figure recommended by the reparations committee in mid-1920 was set at $33 billion.<ref name = "Lords"/> He left before the very end and resigned from the Treasury, writing to Lloyd George: "The battle is lost. I leave the Twins to gloat over the devastation of Europe."<ref name = "Lords"/> Keynes went on to write [[The Economic Consequences of the Peace]], where he warned of the grave consequences of continuing to inflict excessive punishment on the German people. According to Ahamed<ref name = "Lords"/> and historian [[Carroll Quigley]], reparations remained a key global issue for the two decades after the war, consuming statesmen's energies and attention more than any other issue.<ref name ="Hope"/>
==Criticism== According to civil servant [[James Wycliffe Headlam|James Headlan-Morley]], who was also present at Versailles, the Twins acted as "the two bad men of the conference … always summoned when some particularly nefarious act has to be committed". The Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs [[Robert Cecil, 1st Viscount Cecil of Chelwood|Lord Cecil]], referring to Lord Sumner, had said "Some very able lawyers can be very cruel men". For the British Prime Minister they were "singularly able men", whose help was crucial in securing an increased share of the reparations,<ref name = "Guilt" /> but Lloyd George was also to record in his memoirs that he had felt trapped by the Twins into pushing for higher reparations than he would have preferred.<ref name = "companion"/>
In the following decades, the French were often primarily blamed for the high payments imposed<ref name = "origins"/> and Britain second though, due to the influence of the Heavenly Twins and the intrigues at Versailles rather than intent by her leaders. An exception was in Germany, where economic writer [[James Orlin Grabbe|James Grabbe]] has stated that the common view in the 1930s was that Britain had desired to economically cripple Germany even as early as 1916, as expressed in this 1934 quote from German historian [[Oswald Spengler]]:<ref name = "IFM">{{cite book | last = Orlin | first = Crabbe | title = International Financial Markets | year = 1996 | edition =3rd | pages = 2–12 | isbn = 0-13-206988-1 | publisher =Prentice Hall}}</ref> {{quote|The war of 1914, however, was fought by England, not on France's behalf nor on Belgium's, but for the sake of the 'week-end,' to dispose of Germany, if possible, for good, as an economic rival. In 1916 there set in, side by side with the military war, a systematic economic war, to be carried on when the other came inevitably to an end . . . The Treaty of Versailles was not intended to create a state of peace but to organize the relation of forces in such a way that this aim could at any time be secured by fresh demands and measures. Hence the handing over of the colonies and the merchant fleet, the seizure of bank bonds, property, and patents in all countries, the severance of industrial areas like Upper Silesia and the Saar valley, the inauguration of the Republic—by which it was expected (and correctly) that industry would be undermined by the power assumed by trade unions—and finally the reparations, which England, at least, intended not as war indemnification but as a permanent burden on German industry until it should collapse.}}
In 1916 the conservative coalition that acted as the Heavenly Twins power base had yet to form. Modern historians do not endorse Spengler's view, but they have questioned whether the twin's influence at Versailles was really decisive. Were they really formidable enough that the archetypal "man of power" Lloyd George, with his "lightning ingenuity" and uncanny psychological insight,<ref name = "Guilt"/> would really have been helpless before them? Antony Lentin thinks not, suggesting that Lloyd George had secretly wanted high reparations to be imposed and had set the Twins up as scapegoats. According to Lentin "He was never in thrall to the Twins: they were the obedient agents of his bidding."<ref> {{cite web |url= http://www.history.ac.uk/reviews/paper/sharpa.html |title= A Review of Lloyd George and the Lost Peace |publisher= Institute of Historical Research |author= Professor Alan Sharp |accessdate=2009-06-19}} </ref>
==Notes and references== {{reflist}}
