'''Mary Thipe''' was a [[South African]] anti-apartheid and human rights activist who took part in the [[1956 Women's March]] against apartheid pass laws, the [[South African potato boycott]] of 1959 and the [[Cato Manor]] Beer Hall boycott in the same year. Thipe was also the vice-chairperson of the [[Cato Manor]] branch of [[African National Congress Women's League]] (ANCWL) during the 1950s.<ref name="Thipe1">{{cite web| title=Mary Thipe |publisher=The Presidency| url=http://www.thepresidency.gov.za/national-orders/recipient/mary-thipe-posthumous| accessdate=25 October 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life==
Mary Thipe was born in 1917 in a village called Ramhlakoane in the [[Matatiele]] district in the [[Eastern Cape]], [[South Africa]]. She later moved to Umkhumbane in [[KwaZulu Natal]] and joined the liberation struggle in 1952.<ref name="Thipe1"/> Thipe had six children, five daughters and one son. After joining the struggle for liberation, Thipe was arrested on numerous occasions, making it difficult to spend time with her children. In describing her upbringing, Thipe's daughter Maeketso said: "We were raised by our father and some of our neighbours because my mother was arrested so many times. Sometimes people would laugh at us telling us our mother was in jail. It was hard. My mother never ever had a good life." Thipe died of a heart attack in 1982.<ref name="Thipe2">{{cite web| title=Daughter honours late anti-apartheid activist mother|publisher=SABC| url=http://www.sabc.co.za/news/a/16b23f004dcdd13bb72bffbc7090c397/Daughterundefinedhonoursundefinedlateundefinedanti-apartheidundefinedactivistundefinedmother-20160908| accessdate=25 October 2017}}</ref>
==Political work==
Mary Thipe joined the [[ANC]] during the [[Defiance Campaign]] of 1952. Thipe went on to become vice-chairperson of the [[Cato Manor]] branch of the [[African National Congress Women's League]] (ANCWL). She took a train from [[Cato Manor]], [[KwaZulu-Natal]] to [[Pretoria]] to join hundreds of women who marched against pass laws on August 9, 1956. In an interview with the [[SABC]], Thipe's daughter Maeketso said her mother refused to own a pass. "One day they [apartheid police] came to our house. It was in the middle of the day and they came and wanted to see her dompass. She didn't have it and she told them that she would not carry it. They arrested her. She spent two weeks in jail," Maeketso said.<ref name="Thipe2"/>
On 26 June 1959, Thipe and leaders of the [[ANC]]-aligned [[South African Congress of Trade Unions]] and [[Congress Alliance]], launched the national potato boycott in response to the unsatisfactory working conditions of labourers in Bethal in the Eastern Transvaal, now known as [[Mpumalanga]]. Over 60, 000 people attended the launch of the boycott at Currie's Fountain in [[Durban]]. The boycott lasted until September 1959 after the farmers improved the conditions in the farms. The boycott is seen as one of the most successful boycotts led by the ANC and allies during the apartheid era. On 17 June 1959, women led by Thipe and Dorothy Nyembe attacked the [[Cato Manor]] beer hall, forced their way inside, beating the men drinking there and wrecking the place. Rioting continued the next day and beer halls in other parts of town were attacked. This riot was organised to stop men from drinking sorghum beer while their children and wives starved.<ref name="Thipe1"/>
Thipe's political work caught the attention of the apartheid government. She was put under house arrest for 10 years which meant she could not attend church services, funeral services of her loved ones and was not allowed to be in the company of more than three people. Every Monday morning, Thipe was required to report at the [[Cato Manor]] police station. This did not stop the security branch from harassing her even in her house arrest.<ref name="Thipe1"/>
She had trained her children that each time police came in the middle of the night, they would wake up and stand behind her. She had also trained them to look at the police in the eye and not flinch. When three of Thipe's children went into exile, the police intensified their terror on Thipe and her family.<ref name="Thipe1"/> "They would come wake us up, wanting to know where our siblings are. When I went to college, they had someone keep tabs on me. They told me I am not allowed to participate in politics because my family was already in big trouble," said Thipe's daughter Maeketsi in an interview with SABC.<ref name="Thipe2"/>
When the police threatened to find Thipe's grandson and kill him, she retorted by requesting that they bring his head back to her. She refused to show fear and flinch at their threats. Even in the house arrest Thipe found ways to continue her work with the ANCWL, organising funerals of fallen comrades.<ref name="Thipe1"/>
== Legacy==
Thipe is regarded as one of the women who were instrumental in the fight against apartheid in South Africa. A road in [[Durban]] is named after Thipe in honour of her work in the Chesterville and Ntuzuma townships of [[Durban]].<ref name="Thipe1"/> The Mary Thipe Scholarship, which seeks to help students from poor families was launched in honour of her political work in Umkhumbane, [[Cato Manor]] and Chesterville in 2001.<ref name="Thipe3">{{cite web| title=Fund named after struggle stalwart|publisher=Izwi| url=http://www.cmda.org.za/IZWI/Izwi_Mar01_pg2.htm| accessdate=25 October 2017}}</ref> In April 2015, she was awarded the Order of Luthuli in Silver for her contributions to the South African struggle for freedom.<ref name="Thipe1"/>
==See also== [[Beer Hall Boycott]] [[Women's March (South Africa)]]
==External links== * [https://mg.co.za/article/2016-08-25-60-iconic-women-the-people-behind-the-1956-womens-march-to-pretoria-41-50/ 60 Iconic Women — The people behind the 1956 Women's March to Pretoria]
==References==

{{Infobox person | name = María Rosa Urraca Pastor | image = HJJ.17.87.44.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = María Rosa Urraca Pastor | birth_date = {{Birth year|1900}} | birth_place = [[Madrid]], Spain | death_date = {{Death year and age|1984|1900}} | death_place = [[Barcelona]], Spain | body_discovered = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = orator, propagandist, politician, nurse | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | notable works = | occupation = teacher | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party =[[:es:Comunión Tradicionalista|Comunión Tradicionalista]], [[Falange|Falange Española Tradicionalista]] | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = | misc = }} '''María Rosa Urraca Pastor''' (1900–1984)<ref>María Dolores Andrés Prieto, ''La mujer en la política y la política de la memoria. María Rosa Urraca Pastor, una estrella fugaz'' [MA thesis in Gender Studies], Salamanca 2012, p. 16; some sources claim she was born 1908, see ''María Rosa Urraca Pastor'' entry [in:] ''euskomedia'' service, available [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/135168 here], or Iker Gonzalez-Allende, ''¿Ángeles en la batalla?: Representaciones de la enfermera en Champourcin y Urraca Pastor durante la guerra civil española'' [paper of Modern Languages and Literatures Department, University of Nebrasca], Lincoln 2009, p. 86. According to a municipal record of Barcelona reproduced by ''familysearch'' (available [https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/3:1:939D-6DPB-F?mode=g&i=91&wc=QZ7W-XYS%3A335015101%2C335015102%2C335272101%3Fcc%3D2015324&cc=2015324 here]) she was born on December 31, 1899</ref> was a Spanish [[Carlist]] politician and propagandist. She is known mostly as a thrilling orator, one of the best public speakers of the [[Second Spanish Republic]]. She is also noted as head of Delegación Nacional de Frentes y Hospitales, the [[Nationalist faction (Spanish Civil War)|Nationalist]] [[Spanish Civil War|wartime]] organization catering for the wounded.
==Family and youth== [[File:MMN.14.887.JPG|thumbnail|left|[[Bilbao]] around 1900]] María Rosa Urraca Pastor's paternal family originated from [[Rioja Province|La Rioja]].<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 18</ref> Her grandfather, Modesto Urraca Victoria,<ref>Juan Urraca Sáenz's certificate of birth, available [http://s9.postimg.org/egl504xnj/Partida_Juan_Urraca_Saenz.jpg here]</ref> a native of [[Grañón]], was the first reservoir keeper of the [[:es:Embalse de La Grajera|pantano de la Grájera]].<ref>''Boletín Oficial de la provincia de Logroño'' 25.08.1882, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?posicion=3&path=2293713&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Her father, [[Juan Urraca Sáenz]] (1873-1965),<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 24.04.65, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1965/04/15/pagina-27/33552088/pdf.html here]</ref> was born in [[Nalda]], near [[Logroño]]. He joined the army and took part in unspecified combat missions, probably during the [[Spanish–American War]].<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 24.04.65</ref> Back in Spain he first served in [[Madrid]],<ref>Antonio Manuel Moral Roncal, ''María Rosa Urraca Pastor: de la militancia en Acción Católica a la palestra política carlista (1900–1936)'', [in:] ''Historia y política: Ideas, procesos y movimientos sociales'' 26 (2011), p. 201</ref> assigned later to [[Burgos]]<ref>''La Rioja'' 31.01.07, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=3081931&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and finally in the early 20th century to Comisaría de Guerra de [[Bilbao]]. In 1913 he was transferred to Cuerpo Auxiliar de Intervención Militar, an intendancy and fiscal administration structure of the military. He first served as modest rank of auxiliar de tercera clase,<ref>''La Correspondencia Militar'' 06.01.13, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002039273&page=2 here], later promoted to 2nd class, ''La Correspondencia Militar'' 07.05.13, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002045070&page=3 here]</ref> shortly before retirement promoted to auxiliar mayor in 1928.<ref>''Diario Oficial de Ministerio de la Guerra'' 25.08.28, p. 565, available [http://bibliotecavirtualdefensa.es/BVMDefensa/i18n/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=13888 here], Antonio Manuel Moral Roncal, ''Auge y caída de una líder carlista en le franquismo: María Rosa Urraca Pastor'', [in:] ''Aportes: Revista de historia contemporánea'' 81 (2013), p. 65</ref> At unspecified time he married Rafaela Pastor Ortega (died 1941)<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 21.12.41, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1941/12/21/pagina-7/33108627/pdf.html here]</ref> a native of [[Villahoz]] ([[Province of Burgos|Burgos]]).<ref>Rafaela Pastor Ortega's certificate of death, available [http://postimg.org/image/4fagveyzr/ here]</ref> It is not clear how many children the couple had; none of the sources consulted refers to María's siblings.<ref>both the 1941 obituary of the mother (''La Vanguardia'' 21.12.41, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1941/12/21/pagina-7/33108627/pdf.html here]) and her certificate of death (available [http://postimg.org/image/4fagveyzr/ here]) refer only to María Rosa as her child</ref>
Though María Rosa was born in Madrid, at the age of 3 she followed her father's professional lot and in her early childhood the family moved from the capital to Burgos<ref>J.F.F., ''Urraca Pastor (María Rosa)'' entry, [in:] ''Enciclopedia Espasa'', Supplement, Madrid 1935 [1980 reprint, {{ISBN|8423945847}}], p. 179</ref> and then to Bilbao.<ref>''María Rosa Urraca Pastor, Así empezaron'', [in:] ''Fundacion Nacional Francisco Franco'' website, available [http://www.fnff.es/Maria_Rosa_Urraca_Pastor_Asi_empezaron_914_c.htm here]</ref> She was raised in fervently Catholic ambience, as her father was member of a number of local religious societies like Hermandad de Nuestra Señora de Valvanera;<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 24.04.65</ref> he passed the pious zeal to the daughter.<ref>„a él [father] y a mi madre debo el caldo de cultivo en que crecí: familia profundamente cristiana y practicante", ''La Vanguardia'' 05.11.82, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1982/11/05/pagina-6/32955578/pdf.html here]</ref> Nothing is known of political views of María's parents, except that her father was a non-Carlist [[monarchist]].<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1972/01/26/pagina-41/34279217/pdf.html here]; in 1982 she confirmed that „no soy hija de carlista", ''La Vanguardia'' 05.11.82</ref> Another feature of her upbringing was profound respect for the military, considered „backbone of the nation".<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 49</ref> Her early formation was completed by books; she later admitted that at the age of 14 she had been profoundly moved by the works [[Concepción Arenal]]<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 65</ref> and [[Graciano Martínez]].<ref>Moral Roncal 2011, p. 202, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 65</ref> The former advocated active public stance of women in the modern society; the latter, a Catholic friar, pursued the regenerationist path by focusing on social work of the Christians, also underlining the role of females. [[File:HJJ.13.11.54.jpg|thumbnail|[[Physical education|PE]] at Escuelas Ave Maria]] It is not clear where María received her primary education; she later frequented Escuela Normal Superior de Maestras de Vizcaya, graduating in 1923.<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 25, 41, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 201</ref> It is also not evident whether she has ever pursued the university path; herself she claimed having studied Filosofía y Letras, though neither the timing nor location are known; according to her later account, she followed the classes of [[Miguel de Unamuno]] and [[Julián Besteiro]].<ref>she admits having listened to Besteiro and Unamuno, ''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72</ref> Vivacious, straightforward and vibrant,<ref>„me gustaban [...] llevar melena y falda corta", Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 41</ref> Urraca commenced her professional career by teaching at La Obra del Ave-María,<ref>Moral Roncal 2011, p. 206, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 67</ref> a network of Catholic schools founded by [[Andrés Manjón]] and focused on poverty-stricken children, at unspecified time in the 1920s acting as directora of the Bilbao branch.<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 42</ref> She also became auxiliary teacher at Escuela Normal de Bilbao, at that time considered „universidad femenina".<ref>Moral Roncal 2011, p. 203, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 65</ref> Urraca Pastor has never married and has had no children.
==Early public activity==
Urraca first spoke publicly in 1923 during Semana Pedagogica in Bilbao.<ref>''Urraca Pastor (María Rosa)'' entry, [in:] ''Enciclopedia Espasa'' p. 179</ref> In the mid-1920s she entered [[Acción Católica de la Mujer]];<ref>Moral Roncal 2011, p. 204</ref> her insatiable character and a knack for letters produced the 1925 appointment to manager of ''Boletín de la ACM de Vizcaya''.<ref>Moral Roncal 2011, p. 204, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 66</ref> Some scholars claim that by the end of the decade she became president of the entire Bilbao section of ACM.<ref>Brian D. Bunk, ''Ghosts of Passion: Martyrdom, Gender, and the Origins of the Spanish Civil War'', Durham 2007, {{ISBN|9780822339434}}, p 39, Miren Llona González, ''El feminismo católico en los años veinte y sus antecedentes ideológicos'', [in:] ''Vasconia'' 25 (1998), p. 296</ref> Urraca got enthusiastically involved in a number of social, charity and educational initiatives of the organization, at that time very much encouraged by the [[Miguel Primo de Rivera|Primo de Rivera]] dictatorship.<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 22, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 206</ref> In the mid-1920s she became engaged in the nascent radio broadcasting; she was noted by the press as occasionally on air giving lectures on cultural subjects<ref>like lecture on „Cantos Asturianos" in 1925, ''El Sol'' 15.06.25, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000309378&page=4 here].</ref> and commenced close co-operation with ''T.S.H.'', a weekly issued by [[Asociación Radio Española]]. She also admitted contributing to ''[[El Sol (Madrid)|El Sol]]'', a Madrid daily of Liberal leaning, though nature of this engagement is rather obscure.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72</ref>
The young María Rosa became a role model for a new breed of Catholic female public activists,<ref>she was not first Carlist female propagandist. In the 1930s [[Dolores Gortázar Serantes]] was hailed as a veteran Carlist woman writer, yet her propaganda activity was formatted along 19th century lines. Urraca had no problem engaging in mixed-sex initiatives. Gortázar excelled in small, dedicated groupings, Urraca starred in broad-scale, general organizations. Gortázar focused on cultural and educational activities, Urraca engaged in open politics. Gortázar was brilliant in behind-the-scene, closed meetings, Urraca was an excellent speaker at mass rallies</ref> opposed to the old-style Catholic wife and mother epitome and throwing themselves in social and education work. A number of senior nationwide ACM militants – including her idol, Carmen Cuesta<ref>whom she considered th best female speaker ever, ''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72</ref> - entered the primoderiverista quasi-parliament, [[:es:Asamblea Nacional Consultiva|Asamblea Nacional Consultiva]]; riding the wave of regime's modernizing attempts and its support for females activists, Urraca was appointed to the official labor administration.<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 42</ref> In 1929 she was nominated Inspectora De Trabajo,<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72, Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 42</ref> which converted her standing from a Catholic social worker to a state official. She took part in schemes like Patronato De Previsión Social de Vizcaya and Patronato Nacional De Recuperación De Inválidos Para El Trabajo.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72, Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 43, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 207</ref> She started to address social issues by publishing in the press, be it local Biscay titles like ''[[:es:El Nervión|El Nervión]]'', ''[[:es:La Gaceta del Norte|La Gaceta del Norte]]'' and ''El Pueblo Vasco''<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72</ref> or national ones like ''La Nación''.<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 43, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 202, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 65</ref> Urraca also started to gain recognition beyond [[Biscay]]: professional duties brought her to other regions<ref>e.g. to Catalonia</ref> and ACM assignment enabled her to take part in 1929 Congreso Femenino Hispanoamericano, staged by the organization in [[Seville]].<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 43, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 207, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 67</ref> [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-11543, Madrid, Ausrufung der Zweiten Spanischen Republik.jpg|thumbnail|[[Second Spanish Republic|Republic]] declared, 1931]] Urraca considered the fall of the monarchy a national disaster.<ref>she cried having learnt the fall of the monarchy, Frances Lannon, ''The Spanish Civil War, 1936–1939'', London 2002, {{ISBN|9781841763699}}, p. 83, she cried, Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 23</ref> Almost immediately she engaged in public rallies either in favor of the monarchy<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 48</ref> or protesting against militantly secular policy of the Republic.<ref>Lannon 2002, p. 83</ref> Already in May 1931 she was detained and fined 500 pesetas for promoting a meeting classified as non-constitutional conspiracy.<ref>Lannon 2002, p. 83, ''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72, Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 55, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 208</ref> She seemed politically disoriented; due to her earlier engagements she was considered sort of a socialist,<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72, she gained local renown engaged in struggle to gain better conditions for female textile workers, Lannon 2002, p. 83</ref> ACM record made her look towards Christian organizations, in the April 1931 elections Urraca worked as propagandist supporting [[Alfonsism|Alfonsine]] candidates<ref>Moral Roncal 2011, p. 208, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 67; the 1931 appearances in favor of Alfonsist candidates were her first public political addresses, ''Urraca Pastor (María Rosa)'' entry, [in:] ''Enciclopedia Espasa'' p. 180</ref> and she neared [[José María Albiñana]] and his Legionarios.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72</ref> In late 1931 she co-organized Agrupación de Defensa Femenina, a conservative female organization grouping Alfonsine monarchists, Carlists and the [[Basque people|Basque]] Emakumes,<ref>Moral Roncal 2011, p. 209, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 69</ref> and was later asked to write the program draft.<ref>Moral Roncal 2011, p. 209</ref> Extremely active, she helped to organize 50 meetings during four months.<ref>Moral Roncal 2011, pp. 209-10</ref> In 1932 she was fired as labor inspector.<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, pp. 43, 69</ref>
==Carlist== When detained, active in joint right-wing women groupings or collecting funds to pay fines, Urraca started to meet and forged closer relations with female Carlists;<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72</ref> she was particularly impressed by María Ortega de Pradera, local ACM leader and wife of the [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalist]] theorist [[Víctor Pradera Larumbe|Victor Pradera]].<ref>she was presidenta de Junta Diocesiana de ACM de San Sebastián, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 205-6, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 66</ref> She later claimed having been fascinated by their unshaken Christianity, valiance and fortitude,<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 50</ref> especially against the bewilderment of the Alfonsine monarchism.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72</ref> During the winter of 1931-1932 she neared the Carlists, starting to appear on their public rallies and quickly becoming sort of a rising star of the Carlist propaganda; her earlier combined experience in ACM, broadcasting, schools and newspapers turned her into a thrilling orator.<ref>Robert Vallverdú i Martí, ''El Carlisme Català Durant La Segona República Espanyola 1931–1936'', Barcelona 2008, {{ISBN|9788478260805}}, pp. 96, 101, 129</ref> Already in 1932 she was speaking at Carlist and Catholic meetings all over Spain,<ref>e.g. in like Andalusia, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 210</ref> appearing among top Traditionalist politicians and most distinguished female activists.<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 69. Among the Carlist speakers she was among those who emphasized the social threads the most, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 214</ref> Urraca contributed also to Carlist press,<ref>''El Pensamiento Navarro'', ''El Pensamiento Alavés'', ''La Unión de Sevilla'' and ''Boletín de Orientación Tradicionalista'', Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 68; she also formed editorial board of ''Ellas. Semanario de las mujeres españolas'' (1932-4), see [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/details.vm?q=id:0003716921< here]</ref> activity which triggered further fines.<ref>e.g. for writing that the Azaña government is morally responsible for the Casas Viejas incident, Martin Blinkhorn, ''Carlism and Crisis in Spain 1931–1939'', Cambridge 2008, {{ISBN|9780521207294}}, p. 99</ref> In 1933 she was already sort of a Carlist celebrity, acclaimed by their political leaders.<ref>Moral Roncal 2011, p. 213-4</ref> and called omnipresent.<ref>Vallverdú i Martí 2008, p. 251, Jordi Canal i Morell, ''El carlismo: dos siglos de contrarrevolución en España'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|8420639478}}, pp. 294-7</ref> She was noted by political opponents: [[Indalecio Prieto]] ridiculed her in the press stating that "the cavemen got their miss",<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72, Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 66, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 210, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 69; hostile press was also ridiculing her family name; urraca in Spanish means magpie, see ''Vida Nueva. Órgano de la UGT y del PSOE'' 07.07.33</ref> to which the Carlist [[Requetés]] responded by greeting her with "Long Live Miss Cavemen" cry.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 211, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 70</ref>
In the [[Spanish general election, 1933|1933 elections]] she [[Electoral Carlism (Second Republic)|ran for the Cortes]] from [[Gipuzkoa]] as Carlist representative in Unión Regionalista Gipuzcoana;<ref>she did not want to run, but was persuaded to, initially on Candidatura Católico-Agraria de La Rioja, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 72</ref> greeted by the Republican press as „candidatura de la Edad Media, típicamente troglodita",<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 70, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 215</ref> she narrowly missed the election.<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 70, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 215; having gained 31618 votes she missed 1702, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 72</ref> Embittered by backstage political haggling<ref>taking place and concluded that „la Comunión Tradicionalista me ha vendido por unas miserables pesetas Moral Roncal 2011, p. 216, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 72</ref> Urraca was disillusioned by parliamentary politics;<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 71</ref> she went on with hectic propaganda activity across Spain, gaining nationwide recognition as an inflammatory and thrilling orator and greeted by homages from the Right and abuse from the Left.<ref>Moral Roncal 2011, p. 216; during public gatherings she was whistled down by the Falangists, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 280</ref> As Carlist leaders realized how important the female votes were<ref>Fal Conde claimed that the Right won the 1933 elections mostly thanks to female votes; hence, he appreciated the need to keep the feminine electorate militant on his side, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 218</ref> she gained weight within the movement and entered correspondence with the Carlist queen, [[Infanta Maria das Neves of Portugal|María de las Nieves]].<ref>Moral Roncal 2011, p. 216-7</ref> [[File:María Rosa Urraca.jpg|thumbnail|160px|Urraca speaking, 1934]] Following organizational shakeup of the party executive in 1934, the new leader [[Manuel Fal Conde|Manuel Fal]] entrusted her with re-modeling the Secciones Femeninas of [[:es:Comunión Tradicionalista|Comunión Tradicionalista]].<ref>most refer to her as „key activist", see Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 71</ref> Female groupings, known as Margaritas, operated as affiliated with local circulos; apart from boosting membership and launching new activities, Urraca was entrusted with turning the organization from very loose federation into a nationwide structure; since the task has never been fully completed she did not assume formal presidency,<ref>Moral Roncal 2013, p. 73-4</ref> though some scholars name her de facto leader.<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 212, She was not just a follower, but laid out her own ideas how to organize female structures, compare her ''Una idea y un proyecto. A las organizaciones femeninas tradicionalistas de España'', published in ''El Siglo Futuro'' 29.01.34</ref> Up to 1936 Margaritas recruited 23,000 women,<ref>compared to 70,000 of Juventud Femenina de Acción Católica</ref> mostly in [[Valencia province|Valencia]], [[Navarre]] and [[Names of the Basque Country (in Spanish)|Vascongadas]].<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 72. In Navarre, there were 4.923 women in 33 agrupaciones, in the Vascongadas accordingly 4.350 and 50, in Valencia 6.555 and 60, in Barcelona 1.647 and 28, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 221</ref> Urraca encouraged them to take courses in nursing (and took it herself),<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 53-4</ref> getting ready to the anticipated violent overthrow of the Republic. In [[Spanish general election, 1936|1936]] she unsuccessfully run for the parliament again, this time from [[Teruel Province|Teruel]].<ref>despite a massive support campaign organised by various Carlist structures Moral Roncal 2011, p. 221-2</ref> Urraca continued her favorite social activities setting up Socorro Blanco, the Carlist relief organization.<ref>it was set up to assist the members fined, imprisoned or otherwised penalised by the Republic, Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 71-2, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 219, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 74</ref> In the movement's press she campaigned for Spiritual Crusade of Prayer.<ref>intended as a campaign of prayer and self-sacrifice Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 72, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 220, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 74</ref> In April 1936 she was detained for illegal possession of a pistol<ref>when visiting a requete in a Madrid hospital she was searched and a hidden pistol was discovered, Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 87; slightly different version of the incident in Moral Roncal 2013, p. 64</ref> but was smuggled out of custody and spent the last few months of peace hiding in a village of [[Arcos de la Llana]] near Burgos.<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 72, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 64</ref>
==Civil war==
In [[Aranda de Duero]] Urraca joined the Navarrese troops commanded by [[:es:Francisco García-Escámez|García Escámez]] and heading for Madrid.<ref>incorporated into Servicios de Sanidad Moral Roncal 2013, p. 76, Pablo Larraz Andía, Víctor Sierra-Sesúmaga Ariznabarreta, ''Requetés: de las trincheras al olvido'', Madrid 2011, {{ISBN|8499700462}}, 9788499700465, p. 212, Julio Aróstegui, ''Combatientes Requetés en la Guerra Civil española, 1936–1939'', Madrid 2013, {{ISBN|9788499709758}}, p. 436</ref> On the intermittent basis she served as nurse on the [[Sierra de Guadarrama|Guadarrama]] front;<ref>„Urraca had now experienced all the excitements of the battle – bomb explosions from aviation, shell bursts from artillery, and now flying bullets; the only thrill missing was a grenade attack, immediately rectified by a grenade burst a few metres above", Nicholas Coni, ''Medicine and Warfare: Spain, 1936–1939'', New York 2013, {{ISBN|9781134170692}}, p. 45</ref> during breaks<ref>e.g. Lannon 2002, p. 83, Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 88; in October 1936 she moved to the Biscay section of the Northern front - Lannon 2002, p. 83, Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 88, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 79; her father was incarcerated by the Republicans and her mother was ill; she wrote to the Carlist king Alfonso Carlos so that he works with German and Austrian diplomatic services and get her father is released, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 79</ref> she engaged in propaganda work<ref>e.g. radio broadcasts, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 77</ref> and threw herself into organizing Carlist medical services, mostly recruiting women as nurses and auxiliary staff. November 1936 back in Guadarrama<ref>Moral Roncal 2013, p. 81</ref> she spent Christmas among the soldiers,<ref>Moral Roncal 2013, p. 82</ref> but moved – still as a nurse - to the [[War in the North|Northern front]] in early 1937, partially present during the Nationalist conquest of Vascongadas. In immediate vicinity of the frontline Urraca made a picturesque figure; apart from typical medical activities she dispensed [[cognac]] at arbitrary doses to the wounded.<ref>Coni 2013, pp. 45-6</ref> According to some testimonies, she inflicted her Christian compassion upon the otherwise fanatical Carlist soldiers and prevented Nationalists from executing the Republican prisoners;<ref>see the account of Ernesto Carratala, a communist and well-known professor of linguistics in Barcelona, who claims when upon having been captured as Republican POW in Sierra de Guadarrama, he got his wounds treated by Urraca herself; later she confronted the crowd of Falangists and Requetes and prevented his execution, ''La Vanguardia'' 10.09.99, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1999/09/10/pagina-28/34496361/pdf.html here]; see also the story of a Nationalist soldier „shouting abuse at prisoners. She reminded him of his Spanish chivalry and his Christian charity, and such were her powers of persuasion that he finished up sharing his rations and his tobacco with the prisoners", Coni 2013, p. 45, also Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''La continuidad ideológica del carlismo tras la Guerra Civil'' [PhD thesis in Historia Contemporanea, Universidad Nacional de Educación a Distancia], Valencia 2009, p. 86</ref> she also publicly defended some captured Republicans accused of crimes.<ref>„otro desconocido ejemplo de intercesión de la líder carlista se produjo al ańo siguiente, cuando realizado declaración escrita a favor de Ernesto Ricort Vivó, en el juicio contra el chequista socialista Agapito García Atadell, al que se acusó de complicidad", Moral Roncal 2013, p. 78</ref> Other accounts point to her cruelty and suggest that she was co-responsible for Nationalist atrocities,<ref>see account of José Miguel de Barandiarán, a Catholic priest sympathising with the Basques, who witnessed Mondragón captured by the Nationalist troops; according to his account, Urraca arrived with the front troops, harassed the local parochial priest and murmured „if that were up to me, you would all hang". The priest a number of his associates were indeed executed afterwards, J. M. Gamboa, J. C. Larronde (eds.), ''La guerra civil en Euzkadi. 136 testimonios inéditos recogidos por José Miguel de Barandiaran'', Milafranga 2006, {{ISBN|9788488464033}}</ref> especially for executions of Basque priests.<ref>referred after Martorell Pérez 2009, pp. 98-99</ref> She is also quoted writing that the orphaned Republican children should not be treated the same way as the Nationalist ones.<ref>though she claimed that children can not be held responsible for deeds of their fathers, she also maintained that Republican orphans require additional educational effort, which was not necessary in case of Nationalist orphans, full quotation in Andrés Prieto 2012, pp. 93-4, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 82, Gonzalez-Allende 2009, p. 94</ref>
In late April called to [[Salamanca]] and received by [[Francisco Franco|Franco]],<ref>María Beatriz Delgado Bueno, ''La Sección Femenina en Salamanca y Valladolid durante la guerra civil. Alianzas y rivalidades'' [PhD thesis accepted at Universidad de Salamanca, Faculrad de Historia y Geografia], Salamanca 2009, pp. 81, 247</ref> she entered Sección Femenina of the newly created [[Falange Española Tradicionalista y de las Juntas de Ofensiva Nacional Sindicalista|state party]] and along [[Pilar Primo de Rivera]] and [[:es:Mercedes Sanz-Bachiller|Mercedes Sanz Bachiller]] became one of its leaders. Urraca assumed management of Delegación Nacional de Frentes y Hospitales,<ref>Moral Roncal 2011, p. 222</ref> one of three branches of the Sección<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 76</ref> and entrusted with catering for the wounded. In FET she emerged as one of 3 Carlists among 14 heads of all Delegaciones. In October 1937 she was appointed - as one of 11 Carlists<ref>Canal 2000, p. 340; some sources claim that as one 12 Carlists, César Alcalá, ''D. Mauricio de Sivatte. Una biografía política (1901–1980)'', Barcelona 2001, {{ISBN|8493109797}}, p. 135; the difference stems from treatment of Fal Conde, who was appointed but did not accept</ref> - to the newly established, 50-member [[National Council of the Movement|Consejo Nacional]],<ref>she was one of 3 females appointed, with number 8; Pilar Primo de Rivera came appointed with number 1 and Mercedes Sanz with number 10; Delgado Bueno 2009, p. 266</ref> which triggered her expulsion from Comunión Tradicionalista.<ref>none of the sources consulted explicitly states that Urraca was expulsed, though some claim that all those who accepted seats in Consejo were, see Juan Carlos Peñas Bernaldo de Quirós, ''El Carlismo, la República y la Guerra Civil (1936–1937). De la conspiración a la unificación'', Madrid 1996, {{ISBN|9788487863523}}, p. 297</ref> Engaged in organization and propaganda work, she kept visiting frontlines<ref>e.g. on the Teruel front during the winter of 1937-38, Larraz Andía, Sierra-Sesúmaga Ariznabarreta 2011, p. 335</ref> and was fêted along Nationalist heroes like [[José Moscardó Ituarte|Moscardó]].<ref>Coni York 2013, p. 45</ref> Paradoxically, in the Republican media Urraca enjoyed no lesser popularity than in the Nationalist ones, mocked and ridiculed by the enemy press.<ref>a Madrid ''La Libertad'' deplored Nationalists' forced mobilisation of proletarian women "when ladies and damsels of Urraca Pastor hide in their homes, where they pray for the fascist cause" - ''La Libertad'' 02.11.37, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0003205739&page=1 here],; the anarchist ''Solidaridad Obrera'' informed about the Moroccans raping Republican nurses and asked "what would Urraca Pastor say about this?" - ''Solidaridad Obrera'' 05.12.37, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004921789&page=1 here], while the Barcelona ''La Vanguardia'' ridiculed the propaganda of "doña Urraca" during the battle of Teruel – ''La Vanguardia'' 04.01.38, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1938/01/04/pagina-3/33130565/pdf.html here]. For some reason her person attracted particular attention of the Republican propaganda, which overemphasized her role; she was even reported as a colonel, touring the frontlines by air accompanied by a personal adjutant, ''ABC'' (Madrid) 12.08.36, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1936/08/12/010.html here], or a newly appointed Nationalist minister of industry, ''ABC'' 01.08.36, referred after Moral Roncal 2013, p. 77. The ridiculing of Urraca persisted well into hostile historiography; a British scholar, Paul Preston, defines Delegación de Frentes y Hospitales as „a patrician welfare organization headed by the Carlist Maria Rosa Urraca Pastor", Paul Preston, ''Doves of War: Four Women of Spain'', Boston 2002, {{ISBN|9781555535605}}, p. 35</ref> [[File:Pilar Primo de Rivera.jpg|thumbnail|160px|[[Pilar Primo de Rivera]]]] In Sección Femenina Urraca clashed with Pilar Primo de Rivera. Apart from the rivalry of strong female personalities, the conflict was fuelled by ideological differences between the [[Falange Española de las JONS|original Falange]] and the Comunión.<ref>during the Republic days Urraca was sometimes whistled down by the Falangists Blinkhorn 2008, p. 280</ref> Urraca tried to ensure autonomy of the Delegación against the Falange-dominated Sección.<ref>Moral Roncal 2013, p. 84-5, Delgado Bueno 2009, p. 251</ref> Uneasy relationship developed into open conflict already in 1937,<ref>Delgado Bueno 2009, p. 256</ref> going from bad to worse and culminating in showdown related to personal appointments of provincial Delegación leaders, badges designed for the service and creation of Cuerpo de Enfermeras.<ref>Delgado Bueno 2009, p. 257-8</ref> Primo de Rivera got the upper hand and Urraca resigned from leadership posts in Sección Femenina in July 1938,<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 82, 89, Delgado Bueno 2009, p. 261; she was replaced by Casilda Ampuero</ref> which in some areas led to massive departures of the Margaritas<ref>like Rioja, Mercedes Peñalba Sotorrío, ''Entre la boina roja y la camisa azul, Estella'' 2013, {{ISBN|9788423533657}}, pp, 65, 135</ref> and the ultimate failure of amalgamating Margaritas into FET.<ref>Delgado Bueno 2009, p. 291</ref> Though in 1939 she was confirmed as member of the II. Consejo<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 06.06.39, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1939/02/18/pagina-1/33116357/pdf.html here]</ref> and awarded Cruz Roja del Mérito Militar,<ref>''Boletin Oficial del Estado'' 01.06.39, p. 2996, available [http://bibliotecavirtualdefensa.es/BVMDefensa/i18n/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=16931 here]</ref> Urraca was not appointed to the III. Consejo in 1942 and dropped out of the FET executive,<ref>Moral Roncal 2013, p. 87</ref> soon retiring to privacy and settling temporarily with her parents in [[Zaragoza]].
==Privacy== [[File:Teatro Circo Olympia (Barcelona).jpg|thumbnail|220px|left|Teatro Olympia, Barcelona]] When the civil war ended Urraca was only 39; her hectic activity of the past, abundant with a variety of initiatives and well portrayed in historiography, was to remain in sharp contrast with the next 45 years of her life, spent in privacy and ignored by historians: there is almost no scholarly information on her during that period. Her fate is compared to getting lost in "horror vacui",<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 102</ref> or disappearance in "tierra di nadie".<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 8</ref>
When in Zaragoza Urraca befriended María Pilar Ros Martínez;<ref>widow of the late Carlist Aragon leader [[Jesús Comín Sagüés]]</ref> she was [[Catalan People|Catalan]] herself and persuaded Urraca to move together to [[Barcelona]].<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 22.03.84, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1984/03/22/pagina-67/32838129/pdf.html here]</ref> In 1939 or 1940 Urraca settled with her parents in the Catalan capital.<ref>it might have counted that García Escámez, her old-time commander from the 1936 campaign in Sierra de Guadarrama, was appointed military governor of the province, Moral Roncal 2013, p. 87. In the 1950s she lived at Calle Consejo del Ciento 359, ''La Vanguardia'' 03.03.60, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1960/03/03/pagina-21/32723188/pdf.html here]</ref> In the new setting she turned her home into a cultural circle. In the 1940s Urraca staged regular reunions at home; they were intended as artistic events, often with prestigious guests invited and covering music, painting and theatre.<ref>e.g. honoring musicians (Sorrosal, José Clará y Eduardo Marquina) singers (Gianna Pederzini) or painterns (Fernando Álvarez de Sotomayor, Marcelino Santa María), playing theatrical pieces etc., Moral Roncal 2013, p. 87</ref> She did not resume teaching; in 1940 Urraca started to deliver public lectures.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 07.08.40, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1939/02/18/pagina-3/33117445/pdf.html here]</ref> Advertised in the press as „charlas-recitales", they were usually focusing on arts, though some discussed history and were intended as homage to patriotic virtues. Applauded in the newspapers as „ilustra charlista", she continued on commercial basis until the late 1940s,<ref>the last one identified in appeared in 1947, see ''La Vanguardia'' 19.11.47, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1947/09/25/pagina-9/33101149/pdf.html here]</ref> appearing also in Alava<ref>''Pensamiento alaves' '09.10.40, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=1000032573&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> or Leon.<ref>''Diario de Zamora'' 19.03.44, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=5&path=1000119270&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> The event, typically formatted as a semi-scholarly lecture, in her case was a theatrical monodrama, a genre of stage performance and actually delivered in places like [[:caTeatre Circ Olympia|Teatro Olympia]].<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 05.03.41, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1941/03/05/pagina-4/33112196/pdf.html here]; she also took part in other cultural events, see ''Ritmo'' 01.04.43, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=10&path=1000203421&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> [[File:GBN.19.19.11.jpg|thumbnail|160px|Barcelona, mid-1950s]] In 1940 Urraca published wartime memoirs, titled ''Así empezamos'';<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 89, detailed discussion in Gonzalez-Allende</ref> the work contained repeated homage references to Franco, though was principally designed as praise of males and especially females who contributed to the Nationalist war effort.<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 89-90</ref> The work tended to stay clear of assailing the Republican opponents;<ref>e.g. it emphasized resspect for the enemy wounded, Gonzalez-Allende 2009, p. 93</ref> it highlighted serenity of serving the cause of God and Spain.<ref>Gonzalez-Allende 2009, p. 88</ref> Some scholars point to alleged incompatibility between ever-encompassing maternophilia<ref>Gonzalez-Allende 2009, p. 90</ref> and repeated masculine identifications, both neighboring in the book.<ref>e.g. when stressting that she was a Carlist rather than a Margarita and when she mixed with soldiers, Gonzalez-Allende 2009, p. 103</ref> In Barcelona Urraca set up her own publishing house named MRUPSA,<ref>"María Rosa Urraca Pastor Sociedad Anónima", Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 91</ref> which in the 1940s co-issued two biographical books she had written and edited herself: one dedicated to [[Francis Borgia, 4th Duke of Gandía|Francis Borgia]] and another one to [[Lola Montez|Lola Montes]];<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 91</ref> she also published few books of other authors.<ref>Fernand J. Sautés, ''Autopsia, cara y cruz del drama francés 1939–1944'' (1946), Emilia Pardo Bazán, ''Los pazos de Ulloa'' (1944) and Armie [?], ''Maria Cristina de Habsburgo – reina de España'' (1945). The last one is intriguing not only because of anonymous and unidentified author. The book highlighted the person of the Alfonsist queen, while Urraca was earlier on good personal terms with the Carlist queen</ref> The enterprise ceased to operate in the late 1940s. Later on Urraca kept working on another book, dedicated to [[Mariology]],<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 222</ref> but this one has never appeared in print.
As the family finances were sustained systematically only by military pension of her father, in mid-1950s Urraca started to give lessons in oratory skills.<ref>Moral Roncal 2013, p. 88, the first one identified appeared in 1957, see ''La Vanguardia'' 13.10.57, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1951/12/07/pagina-36/32769752/pdf.html here]</ref> Though initially she advertised also teaching castellano,<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 06.03.58, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1958/02/08/pagina-28/32746764/pdf.html here]</ref> later she dropped this feature from her press ads, which were appearing regularly in the local newspapers until the late 1960s; the last identified was published when she was 70 years old.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 07.10.70, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1969/11/02/pagina-6/34309557/pdf.html here]</ref> Since the death of her father in 1965, having no close family Urraca was increasingly alienated, also by the changing lifestyle patterns of the Spanish society. She maintained particularly close relationship only with María Pilar Comín Ros, almost 20 years her junior and the Barcelona press pundit on women's fashion.
==Late public activity== [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|left|Carlist standard]] Upon termination of Urraca's term in the II. Consejo Nacional of Falange in 1942 she has almost entirely disappeared from politics, be it either this related to official Falangist structures, unofficial Carlist movement or semi-political Catholic organizations. In scholarly works on political life during Francoism she is almost absent, very few times appearing marginally in works dealing with post-war Carlism.<ref>Francisco Javier Caspistegui Gorasurreta, ''El naufragio de las ortodoxias. El carlismo, 1962–1977'', Pamplona 1997; {{ISBN|9788431315641}}, pp. 138, 271, Robert Vallverdú i Martí, ''La metamorfosi del carlisme català: del "Déu, Pàtria i Rei" a l'Assamblea de Catalunya (1936-1975)'', Barcelona 2014, {{ISBN|9788498837261}}, p. 92</ref> Her public activity – apart from organizing reunions, delivering charlas and editorial work, all intended mostly to sustain ailing family finances – was mostly about engagement in local parochial and municipal Christian initiatives. She is noted as busy in apostolate of the lay,<ref>Moral Roncal 2011, p. 222</ref> sort of going on with her earlier teaching work when running cursillos organized by España Cristiana,<ref>Moral Roncal 2013, p. 87</ref> and maintaining interest in social issues by animating Catholic charity.<ref>''CNT'' 27.01.57, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=3088601&presentacion=pagina here]</ref>
In the early 1940s Urraca was still noted as taking part in broad public Carlist initiatives. In 1942 she was among the distinguished guests present at the Montcada i Reixac cemetery, attending memorial service to the fallen requetés and led by the Catalan Carlist leader [[Maurici de Sivatte i de Bobadilla|Maurici de Sivatte]] by the Mausoleum, erected 2 years earlier.<ref>Vallverdú i Martí 2014, p. 92</ref> None of the sources consulted refers to her engagement in Carlist political structures; some authors claim that the Carlists have never forgiven her the 1937-1942 engagement in Falange.<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 93</ref> It is not clear what stand – if any – she took when faced with fragmentation of Carlism, especially the [[Carloctavismo|Carloctavista]] breakup in the 1940s and the Sivattista secession in the 1950s.<ref>e.g. she is only once and very casually mentioned in Vallverdú i Martí 2014, not having been listed at all in César Alcalá, ''D. Mauricio de Sivatte. Una biografía política (1901–1980)'', Barcelona 2001, {{ISBN|8493109797}}, the book which deals extensively with Catalan Carlism of the 1940s, 1950s and 1960s</ref> The official propaganda ignored her; her old-time rival, Pilar Primo de Rivera, made sure Urraca does not grow to prominence and the feminine model she advanced was not in line with masculine domination in public life, advanced by Francoism.<ref>Gonzalez-Allende 2009, p. 99</ref> She is noted, however, as taking part in various commemorative events organized by Catholic or social organizations.<ref>Moral Roncal 2013, p. 88</ref> She also remained in touch with some personalities from both the Carlist and Republican camp.<ref>some time during Francoism visited by Ernesto Carratalá in Barcelona, the Republican POW spared execution due to Urraca's intervention; he brought her flowers; Moral Roncal 2013, p. 78, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 86</ref> [[File:Street photographer in Barcelona.jpg|thumbnail|180px|Barcelona, mid-1970s]] Urraca increased her public profile by the end of her life, re-engaging in Carlism. As at that time the movement was torn between the Traditionalists and the socialists from [[Partido Carlista]], she sided with the former; in 1972 she co-signed a document issued by Junta Nacional del Requeté, which lambasted [[Carlos Hugo]] as the one abandoned the Carlist standard.<ref>Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, p. 138</ref> Urraca remained engaged in anti-hugocarlista backlash also later on, her last voice on the issue was heard in 1974.<ref>Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, p. 271</ref> Also during transición she took part in cultural events related to orthodox Carlism.<ref>she provided a foreword opening a promotional meeting of a book ''El carlismo en el ser de España'' by Felio Villarublas, see ''La Vanguardia'' 15.03.77, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1977/03/15/pagina-44/33631874/pdf.html here]</ref> In return, she was berated by the Partido Carlista propagandists as traitor and "enfermera de Franco".<ref>see the abusive title and contents of a sub-chapter ''María Rosa Urraca Pastor, la enfermera de Franco'', contained in section named ''Gallery of traitors'', replicated in a number of books by Josep Carles Clemente and published until today, e.g. José Carlos Clemente, ''Breve historia de las guerras carlistas'', Madrid 2011, {{ISBN|9788499671697}}, p. 235</ref> In the late 1970s she is known to have neared the post-Francoist [[búnker]]; in 1976 she lent her support to [[Blas Piñar]] and his [[Fuerza Nueva]];<ref>''Fuerza Nueva'' 22.05.76, available [http://ddd.uab.cat/pub/ppc/fuenue/fuenue_a1976m5d22n489.pdf here]</ref> in 1977, shortly before official dissolution of Movimiento Nacional, she still used to frequent its Barcelona premises, recorded as affable, restrained, but energetic and committed to her ideals.<ref>Juan Fernández Krohn, ''Sindrome (joseantoniano) de Alicante'', [in:] ''Juan Fernández Krohn desde Bélgica'' blog, 16.09.2013, available [http://juanfernandezkrohn.blogspot.com/2013/09/sindrome-joseantoniano-de-alicante.html here]</ref> Until her death she considered herself a Carlist. In a letter sent to ''[[La Vanguardia]]'' in 1982, Urraca proudly confirmed her lifetime identity.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 05.11.82; and remained also a fundamentalist Catholic adhering to the Lefebvre format, Krohn 2013</ref>
==Reception and legacy== [[File:The Goblins' Christmas, 28.JPG|thumbnail|140px|left|[[:es:Miguel Bernet Toledano|some]] compared Urraca to a [[witch]]]] In the 1930s hailed by the Right as electrifying orator and ridiculed by the Left as political troglodyte, after the Civil War Urraca has almost fallen into oblivion, save for three of her scarcely popular books. In the tightly censored media of the late 1940s an ex-Republican soldier turned graphics artist, [[:es:Jorge (historietista)|Miguel Bernet Toledano]], was permitted to create and publicize her malicious alter-ego known as [[:es:Doña Urraca (historieta)|Doña Urraca]], a comics figure to become iconic character in the Spanish print. A direct reference has never been made;<ref>there were also some visual differences between a character and its model: Doña Urraca was skinny-thin - Urraca Pastor was well-built, Doña Urraca wore glasses – Urraca Pastor did not, Doña Urraca wore black – Urraca Pastor preferred lighter colours</ref> some claim the cartoon figure had nothing to do with Urraca Pastor,<ref>Krohn 2013; detailed discussion at ''La bruja y los paisanos: Doña Urraca de Jorge y varios señores normales'', [in:] ''De Todo Un Poco'' blog 14.05.2011, available [http://unamiajilladeto.blogspot.com/2011/05/la-bruja-y-los-paisanos-dona-urraca-de.html here]</ref> some maintain that there is little doubt the ugly black-dressed witch, keen to abuse the weak with a sole purpose to do evil<ref>Krohn 2013</ref> was aimed to mock her.<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 94</ref> During transición she took the brunt of long-suppressed Republican anger; a wartime Francoist agent in France, an unrelated Pedro Urraca Rendueles,<ref>Iñaki Mirena Anasagasti Olabeaga, ''Urraca, el policía franquista que lideró agentes y espías en el exterior'', [in:] ''ianasagasti'' blog, available [http://ianasagasti.blogs.com/mi_blog/2013/07/urraca-el-polic%C3%ADa-franquista-que-lider%C3%B3-agentes-y-esp%C3%ADas-en-el-exterior.html here]</ref> was presented as „Urraca Pastor"<ref>''Ressó'' June 1979, p. 14, available [http://xacpremsa.cultura.gencat.cat/pandora/cgi-bin/Pandora.exe here], this either confusion or intended manipulation persisted well into the 1990s, see ''El Pais'' 23.07.96, available [http://elpais.com/diario/1996/07/23/ultima/838072801_850215.html here]</ref> and there was even a 1979 theatric play featuring him as a villain involved in execution of [[Companys]].<ref>''Plaça Gran'' 01.12.79, available [http://xacpremsa.cultura.gencat.cat/pandora/cgi-bin/Pandora.exe here]</ref> Shortly before death she was mocked as a mustached nurse by the Noble-prize winner [[Camilo José Cela|José Cela]] in his ''Mazurca para dos muertos'' (1983); in literature she also appears - as bulky and ugly conspirator - in ''Inquietud en el Paraíso'' (2005) by [[Óscar Esquivias]].
In historiography she is approached as a representative of various social phenomena rather than as a personality herself. One author considers Urraca a typical sample of middle-class women politicized by rocky times of the Second Republic.<ref>Lannon 2002, p. 83</ref> Another scholar advances a competitive thesis, namely that she engaged in public life mostly as a result of modernizing primoderiverista attempts combined with rising social activity of the Catholics.<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 68, Moral Roncal 2011, p. 223</ref> Some point to social issues as a key thread of her activity,<ref>compare Moral Roncal 2011</ref> some point to her traditional Catholicism<ref>compare Gonzalez-Allende 2009</ref> and some focus on [[feminism]].<ref>compare Andrés Prieto 2012</ref> This approach is particularly popular, as Urraca is often mentioned when discussing growing role of women in the recent history of Spain.<ref>see e.g. Isabel Morant Deusa, [[María Ángeles Querol]], ''Historia De Las Mujeres En Espana Y America Latina: Del Siglo XX a Los Umbrales Del Xxi'', Madrid 2005, {{ISBN|9788437622903}}, p. 158; ''Las mujeres y la Guerra Civil española'', Madrid 1991, {{ISBN|9788477990475}}, pp. 18, 189, 296; Mari Luz Esteban, Mila Amurrio, ''Feminist Challenges in the Social Sciences: Gender Studies in the Basque Country'', Reno 2010, {{ISBN|9781935709015}}, pp. 92-93, Llona González 1998</ref> Though in the Basque realm she is held responsible for executions of priests,<ref>''Un libro recoge 136 testimonios inéditos de la Guerra del 36 recogidos por Barandiaran'', [in:] ''Gara'' 25.05.06, available [http://gara.naiz.eus/idatzia/20060525/art165831.php here], ''[[Diario Vasco]]'' 22.10.06, available [http://www.diariovasco.com/prensa/20061022/altodeba/urraca-pastor-amenazo-parroco_20061022.html here]</ref> by many other scholars Urraca is viewed with cautious sympathy, as a person who was allegedly passionate about equality of the sexes,<ref>Lannon 2002, p. 83, though she also „estaba convencida de que la mujer podía servir al país fuera de casa", ''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72</ref> social justice,<ref>„tuve siempre un carácter independiente un instinto de rebeldía contra todo lo injusto. Juzgaba como tal el régimen económico en que vivía la sociedad y me atraía con irresistible vocación la defensa del humilde, del expoliado, del que sufría el despotismo brutal de un sistema positivista que todo lo materializaba, permitiendo la existencia de castas y de clases sociales en lucha permanente" – opinion of Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 49</ref> classless society and post-war reconciliation,<ref>Lannon 2002, p. 83</ref> a victim rather than a culprit.<ref>„High ideas for a better society co-existed with dedication to political movements that were ruthless and vengeful" – opinion of Lannon 2002, p. 83</ref> [[File:Leonid Meteor.jpg|thumbnail|170px|[[María Dolores Andrés Prieto (Spanish nurse and historian)|some]] compared Urraca to ''[[Meteoroid|estrella fugaz]]'']] Except one early re-edition of ''Asi empezamos''<ref>re-published at unspecified time in Barcelona, most likely in the 1940s, see [http://www.todocoleccion.net/militaria-libros-literatura/guerra-civil-asi-empezamos-memorias-una-enfermera-maria-rosa-urraca-pastor-carlista-raro~x48490432 here]</ref> none of Urraca's books has been re-printed. In Carlist historiography she either tends to be ignored by Traditionalist writers<ref>she is not mentioned in a section discussing Margaritas and Socorro Blanco by a classic Traditionalist historian in [[Melchor Ferrer Dalmau|Melchor Ferrer]], ''Breve historia del legitimismo español'', Madrid 1958, pp. 135-6; similarly, she is not a single time mentioned in another classic Carlist work, Roman Oyarzun, ''Historia del carlismo'', Madrid 1969; however, she is a number of times listed in detailed work of Melchor Ferrer, ''Historia del tradicionalismo español'', vol. XXX, Seville 1979</ref> or to be abused by Partido Carlista militants.<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 93</ref> Apart from a handful of related scholarly articles, she has earned one monograph so far, a master thesis in gender studies accepted at [[Universidad de Salamanca]] in 2012. In a remote tiny Andalusian village of La Dehesa there is a street commemorating Urraca Pastor.<ref>Andrés Prieto 2012, p. 92</ref> An internet myth has it – information not confirmed by any scholarly work – that Urraca was responsible for Roman Catholic re-conversion of [[Dolores Ibarruri]] few years before death.<ref>compare comments below ''La Pasionaria, temida líder comunista, se confesó y comulgó antes de morir... católica'', [in:] ''Religión en Libertad'' 11.04.13, available [http://www.religionenlibertad.com/la-pasionaria-temida-lider-comunista-se-confeso-y-comulgo-antes-de-28650.htm here]; Urraca knew Ibarruri from the early Bilbao days and both remained on correct personal terms; their relationship, after the war somewhat cordial, was maintained at a distance even in the early 1970s, when Ibarruri was in Moscow, ''La Vanguardia'' 26.01.72</ref>

María Rosa Urraca Pastor, una estrella fugaz'' [MA thesis], Salamanca 2012 * Martin Blinkhorn, ''Carlism and Crisis in Spain 1931–1939'', London 1987, {{ISBN|9780521086349}} * María Beatriz Delgado Bueno, ''La Sección Femenina en Salamanca y Valladolid durante la Guerra Civil. Alianzas y rivalidades'' [PhD thesis], Salamanca 2009 * Iker González-Allende, ''¿Ángeles en la batalla?: Representaciones de la enfermera en Champourcin y Urraca Pastor durante la guerra civil española'', [in:] ''Anales de la literatura española contemporánea'' 34 (2009), pp. 83–108. * Antonio Manuel Moral Roncal, ''María Rosa Urraca Pastor: de la militancia en Acción Católica a la palestra política carlista (1900–1936)'', [in:] ''Historia y política: Ideas, procesos y movimientos sociales'' 26 (2011), pp. 199–226 * Antonio Manuel Moral Roncal, ''Auge y caída de una líder carlista en le franquismo: María Rosa Urraca Pastor'', [in:] ''Aportes: Revista de historia contemporánea'' 81 (2013), pp. 63–96

[[Kampala]], [[Uganda]] |region_code = |coordinates = |motto = |employees = |budget = |minister1_name = |minister1_pfo = |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = |deputyminister1_name = |deputyminister1_pfo = |deputyminister2_name = |deputyminister2_pfo = |chief1_name = [[Adolf Mwesige]] |chief1_position =
Minister of Defence and Veterans Affairs |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |agency_type = Ministry |parent_department = |parent_agency = |keydocument1 = |website = [http://www.defence.go.ug/ Homepage] |footnotes = |map = |map_width = |map_caption = }} The '''Ministry of Defence and Veterans Affairs''' ('''MODVA''') is a government ministry responsible for the national defence and security of [[Uganda]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.ug/ministry/ministry-defence | title=Government of Uganda: Ministry of Defence and Veterans Affairs| accessdate=15 October 2016 |date=15 October 2016 |location=Kampala | publisher=[[Government of Uganda]] (GOU) | author=GOU}} In this capacity, its role is to preserve, defend and protect the people, property, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Uganda, contributing to regional stability and supporting international peace initiatives.{{cite web| url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/UPDF-sends-2700-troops-to-Somalia--names-new-Commander/688334-2502526-a6ly0g/index.html | title=UPDF sends 2700 troops to Somalia, names new Commander | accessdate=15 October 2016 | date=28 October 2014 | author=Our Reporter | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | location=Kampala}} ==Location== The headquarters of the ministry are located in the Mbuya Military Barracks, on Chwa II Road, in the [[Nakawa Division]] of the city of [[Kampala]], Uganda's capital and largest city.{{cite web|author=John V Sserwaniko| url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200705140987.html | title=Uganda: Defence Headquarters to Relocate to Mbuya | accessdate=15 October 2016| date=14 May 2007 | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] via [[AllAfrica.com]] | location=Kampala}}{{cite web|title=Uganda: Defence Shifts From Bombo to Mbuya | url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200712250020.html | accessdate=15 October 2016 | date=25 December 2007 | first=Grace |last=Matsiko |newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] via [[AllAfrica.com]] | location=Kampala}} The coordinates of the headquarters of the ministry are: 0°19'36.0"N, 32°37'53.0"E (Latitude:0.326656; Longitude:32.631375).{{google maps| url=https://www.google.com/maps/place/0%C2%B019'36.0%22N+32%C2%B037'53.0%22E/@0.3291541,32.6195112,2290m/data=!3m1!1e3!4m5!3m4!1s0x0:0x0!8m2!3d0.326656!4d32.631375 | title=Location of the Headquarters of the Ministry of Defence and Veterans Affairs (Uganda) | accessdate=15 October 2016}} ==Overview== The ministry oversees the [[Uganda People's Defence Forces]] (UPDF). This ensures that the UPDF is ultimately answerable to the people of Uganda, while it remains professional, with focus on protecting its citizens, defending national sovereignty and contributing to regional stability.{{cite web| url=http://www.gov.ug/ministry/ministry-defence | title=Ministry of Defence and Veterans Affairs (Uganda) | publisher=[[Government of Uganda]] (GOU)| date=20 October 2016 | accessdate=20 October 2016 | location=Kampala | author=GOU}} ==Organisational structure== Administratively, the ministry is oranised into three departments: the Department of Administration, Department of Finance, and Department of Logistics. The Permanent Secretary is the Chief Executive and Chief Accounting Officer for the entire ministry. ==Leadership== The ministry is headed by a [[Cabinet of Uganda|cabinet minister]]. The current Minister of Defence, since 6 June 2016, is [[Adolf Mwesige]].{{cite web|url=http://specialforcescommand.go.ug/the-ugandan-minister-of-defense-hon-adolf-kasaija-mwesige/ | title=The Ugandan Minister of Defense, Hon. Adolf Kasaija Mwesige | publisher=Special Forces Command, Uganda People's Defence Force |accessdate=15 October 2016 | last=Facts | date=15 October 2016| location=Entebbe}} He is deputised by the Minister of State, currently [[Colonel]] [[Charles Engola|Charles Engola Okello]].{{cite web| url=http://www.parliament.go.ug/index.php/members-of-parliament/cabinet-members | title=Cabinet Members and Ministers of State | date=15 October 2016 |publisher=[[Parliament of Uganda]] (POU) | author=POU | location=Kampala}} ==Uganda People's Defence Force== {{main|Uganda People's Defence Force}} During the colonial days, the national defence forces were named King's African Rifles (KAR). Later the name changed to Uganda Rifles (UR) and then Uganda Army (UA). The force that fought the [[Uganda Bush War]], from 8 February 1981 to 26 January 1986, was called the National Liberation Army. In 1995, when a new constitution was promulgated, the name was changed to Uganda People's Defence Force.{{cite web| url=http://portal.defence.go.ug:10039/wps/portal/mod-home/armed-forces/updf-links/!ut/p/a1/xVVNc6JAEP0rm4PHOA2IDHubMu5W_Fw1biKX1IgwDsKAMAj46zNaW5WoiSa11i63prtfvX5vpgc56Ak5gm44o5LHgoa72Gk-20PAWhf0DvwiLSCtXgemxsDAk4YqmKkC-OAjcNg_fLAIkJ-_rdGwZ9_fd030iBzkuEImcolmSZxKGn7LuPRqsP0YlsI-bccKdgV6EEuLAmUbax2HNucr8yhtxxZQDOZ6bXgAdvMwDQl1gbphALkhDJw1dpQSyryFl3Em9pHLF2jGyqwqInZbRfnc55yV6cIvlu42iAXj-aIUdOX9EeTMxIeC2EMLiKI2GhntHbWT_pOCC4bsBb1gySVTOpcKFEki5gZmyEk930u9tJ6n6rQspUy-15Q7RVHUFyojXK_O4nrOavBe0zLOJHo6KUYzJYL1hgAmd0D0Fh5P7nSAfhNNTl1JZBSxsKryMihK4VaZH1EebrdFXC5PAPumDsQcaOQHHmug6X8NeMiwbV0ZUGtem-G1AadXB_y6hp1PXC4erNcOUTsnFtIr1en7V0vneNzjq_vuuGdXzXlArXFdwGEbvgzY-cTz8d8MufQKJNE0woHf7TXHuDLCTRQ9Dwa3dI7BMJPN9sFXP_ryNXokNzcvA2eQZQ!!/dl5/d5/L2dBISEvZ0FBIS9nQSEh/ | title=About UPDF | accessdate=20 October 2016 | date=20 October 2016 |publisher=Uganda Ministry of Defence and Veterans Affairs (MoDVA) | author=MoDVA | location=Kampala}} ==See also== * [[Uganda People's Defence Force]] * [[Cabinet of Uganda]] * [[Parliament of Uganda]] * [[Politics of Uganda]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.defence.go.ug/ Website of the Ministry of Defence and Veterans Affairs (Uganda)] {{coor|00|19|36|N|32|37|53|E|display=title}} [[Category:Government ministries of Uganda]] [[Category:Military of Uganda]] [[Category:Defence ministries|Uganda]] [[Category:Veterans' affairs ministries|Uganda]] [[Category:Kampala]]

{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name=Ministry of Defense of the Republic of Kazakhstan |nativename=Қазақстан Республикасының Қорғаныс министрлігі |type=Defense Ministry |logo=File:Flag of Minister of National Defense of Kazakhstan.svg |logo_width= |logo_caption=The flag of the Minister of Defense of Kazakhstan. |seal= |seal_caption= |picture=File:Ministry of Defense Astana.jpg |picture_caption=The headquarters of the ministry. |formed=May 1992 |coordinates= |preceding1=[[Ministry of Defense of the Soviet Union|Ministry of Defense of the Kazakh SSR]] |preceding2= |preceding3= |preceding4= |preceding5= |preceding6= |minister1_name=[[Nurlan Ermekbaev]] |minister1_pfo=Minister of Defense |dissolved= |superseding= |jurisdiction=[[Kazakhstan]] |headquarters=14 Dostyk Street, [[Astana]], [[Kazakhstan]] |parent_department=[[Government of Kazakhstan]] |child1_agency= |website=https://www.mod.gov.kz/ |employees=4,000 |budget= |chief1_name=[[Murat Maikeyev]] |chief1_position=Chief of the General Staff |chief2_name= |chief2_position= |chief3_name= |chief3_position= |chief4_name= |chief4_position= |chief5_name= |chief5_position= |chief6_name= |chief6_position= |chief7_name= |chief7_position= |chief8_name= |chief8_position= |chief9_name= |chief9_position= }} The '''Ministry of Defense of the Republic of Kazakhstan''' ([[Kazakh language|Kazakh]]:Қазақстан Республикасының Қорғаныс министрлігі) is a government agency of Kazakhstan which is the main executive body in implementing military policy. The '''Defense Minister of the Republic of Kazakhstan''' is the head of the Ministry of Defense, whose duties are to exercise the administrative leadership of the [[Armed Forces of the Republic of Kazakhstan]]. The ministry was established in May 1992 and is currently headed by Nurlan Ermekbaev. The first Minister of Defense was Army General Sagadat Nurmagambetov who served from May 1992 to October 16, 1995.
== Functions == The Ministry of Defense conducts the following tasks:<ref>https://www.mod.gov.kz/rus/struktura/ministerstvo_oborony_rk/</ref>
* Implements the state defense policy, military-political and military-economic management of the [[Armed Forces of the Republic of Kazakhstan]] * To act as the headquarters of the armed forces * To carry out its activities in accordance with the [[Constitution of the Republic of Kazakhstan]] * To serve as a legal entity in the organizational and legal form of a state institution * Makes decisions drawn up by orders and directives of the Minister of Defense and [[Kazakh Government]]
== General Staff == [[File:KZDefenseLicensePlate.JPG|thumb|The license plate of a military car belonging to the defense ministry.]] {{See also|Chief of the General Staff (Kazakhstan)}} The '''General Staff of the Armed Forces of the Republic of Kazakhstan''' is the main body for the management of the armed forces of the state in peacetime and wartime, coordinates the development of plans for the construction and development of the Armed Forces, other troops and military formations, their operational, combat and mobilization training, organizes and carries out strategic planning application and interaction of the Armed Forces, other troops and military formations, and also develops a plan for the operational equipment of the country's territory in defense.
== Cadets Corps == The '''Cadet Corps of the Ministry of Defense of Kazakhstan named after [[Shoqan Walikhanov]]''' (Russian: Кадетский корпус Министерства обороны Республики Казахстан имени Чокана Валиханова) is a insitution of the ministry that was formed on 1 July 1996 as a secondary school that prepared Kazakh youth for service in the military and for leadership as junior army, navy, and air force commanders. A similar task is done today by the [[Astana Zhas Ulan Republican School]]. A month after its formation, the corps had 96 enlisted cadets, most of whom came from the [[Alma-Ata Higher All-Arms Command School]] (now the Military Institute of the Kazakh Ground Forces). On its first graduation day on July 29, 1999, where 11 cadets graduated from the corps and enrolled in higher educational institutions, the corps received its own battle flag by the then head of the corps, Colonel Kuangaliev and defense minister [[Mukhtar Altynbayev]]. The corps is currently based in the city of [[Shchuchinsk]] in the [[Akmola Region]].<ref>https://e-history.kz/en/publications/view/3087</ref><ref>https://www.mod.gov.kz/rus/obrazovanie/srednee_obrazovanie/uch_zavedeniya/?cid=0&rid=383</ref>
== List of Defence Ministers of Kazakhstan == [[File:МО РК.jpg|thumb|Nurlan Yermekbayev]]
* [[Sagadat Nurmagambetov]], May 1992 – 16 October 1995, * [[Alybek Kasimov]], 16 October 1995 – 30 October 1996, * [[Mukhtar Altynbayev]], 30 October 1996 – 9 August 1999, * ''vacant from 9 August to 13 October 1999'', * [[Sat Tokpakbayev]], 13 October 1999 – 8 December 2001 * [[Mukhtar Altynbayev]], 8 December 2001 – 10 January 2007 * [[Daniyal Akhmetov]], 10 January 2007 – 24 June 2009 * [[Adilbek Zhaksybekov]], 24 June 2009 – 3 April 2014 * [[Serik Akhmetov]], 3 April – 22 October 2014 * [[Imangali Tasmagambetov]], 22 October 2014 – 13 September 2016 * [[Saken Zhasuzakov]] 13 September 2016 – 7 August 2018 * [[Nurlan Ermekbaev]] since 7 August 2018
